editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE REVENGE: OR, A MATCH IN NEWGATE. A COMEDY. As it was Acted at The Dukes Theatre.
LONDON: Printed for W. Cademan, at the Popes head in the New Exchange. 1680.

div.head: SCENE the Firſt.
div.stage: Enter Sam with Torch, Daſhit raving, followed by Mrs. Daſhit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: RUN, you Rogue, run, raiſe the Street, you Son of a careleſs Whore: Cry, Stop Thief, ſtop Thief!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Which way, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: A Pox of ways: Sirrah, cry, Stop Thief, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: So we may ſtop honeſt men, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: There's no ſuch thing within the Walls of London, ye Rogue; there's nothing but Knaves, Cheats, Cuckolds and Traytors, Thieves and Pickpockets, tho I be one of the Livery. A Pox of Honeſty, my Plate's gone, the Reckoning unpaid, I'm cheated and undone! therefore run, ye Dog, run.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Good ſweet Huſband, have patience.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Patience! yes, ſo you advis'd when I found the Alderman and your Ladyſhip in a civil poſture on the red Couch in the Swan. Patience quotha! Pox of your Remedies. Get ye in, here's Company.

div.stage: Enter Footman with Flambeau, follow'd by Friendly and Wellman.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Whe! how now, Mr. Daſhit, what inrag'd in Rancor, and the Beauty of the London-bars, your Lady too, in Tears! What's amiſs? unfold thy diſmal ſtory.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Onely cheated, robb'd, abus'd, and undone, Sir: that's all, that's all.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: As how, man! Come, advance thy comely Countenance, and do not let thy ſorrowful Snout bedew thy reverend Jerkin. The reaſon, my hardly honeſt Daſhit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p:
Oh Si • , Mr. Trickwell that Knave is this night run
away with our great Gallon-Tankard, ſix ſilver Boats, a great Salt, beſides Spoons and Forks.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Oh, for ſome wiſe man that wou'd but finde 'em out preſently!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Yes, if a wiſe man cou'd be found out preſently.
Friend. How was this Plate loſt? how eſcap'd he unſeen with it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Why, an't like ye, Sir, thus: As I underſtand, that man, man, quoth I? no, rather Monſter, that t'other-end-of-the-Town-Villain, nay, I believe that Jeſuit in diſguiſe, ſent from beyond Sea to ruine honeſt Citizens; I ſay, this Heathen Trickwell comes me into my houſe th • evening with a great two-handed Gentlewoman, or ſome Prieſt in Petticoats; they call for a Room, pretend to ſend a Porter for ſome Ladies of delight, beſpeak a Supper, but no Ladies came.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: My Cockie forgets to tell your Worſhips, that our houſe being full, we had no Room emptie but the great Parlor below ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Hold your peace, hold your peace, I ſay. Am I a Common-Council-man like to be of the Citie of London, and cannot tell my Tale my ſelf? Get ye in, I ſay, and look to what's left.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Well, Sir, on with your Relation.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Well, Sir, a noble Supper they had of the beſt in ſeaſon; I came in, cri'd, Your ſervant, Gentlemen; aſk'd 'em how they lik'd their Wine, and departed civilly: Then enter'd a blinde Harper, crie • , Do ye lack any Muſick, Sir? He cries, Play: The Harper uncaſes, the Drawer is nodded out, who obeys, believing he wou'd be private with the Gentlewoman; and 'tis Sam's part, you know, Sir, to wink at things.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Right and civil.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Aye, aye, but he ſhall anſwer for that winking at the laſt day, I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p:
Well Sir, having eat the Supper, and Trickwell perceiving none in the room but the blinde Harper, whoſe Eyes Heaven had ſhut up from beholding wickedneſs, opens the Caſement to the ſtreet, very patiently packs and pockets up my Plate, unnaturally thruſts the woman out of the window, and himſelf moſt prepoſterouſly with his heels forwards follows. The Harper
plays on, bids the empty Diſhes much good may do 'em, and plays on ſtill. The Drawer returns, cries, What d'ye lack, Gentlemen? but out, alas, the Birds were flown, Sir, flown. Laments are rais'd.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Which did not pierce the Heavens.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Sam cries out; my Wife in the Bar hears the noiſe, and ſhe bawl'd out; I heard her, and thunder'd; the Boys flew like Lightning, and all was in confuſion.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Well, this muſt be for ſome great ſins committed; the ſins of the Bar and Sellar, unmerciful Bills, and ſuffiſticated Wine, my honeſt damn'd Vintner:—Repent, oh repent and mend, and be ſound.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Well, I will hang that Rogue Trickwell, and there's an end on't: I'll do't; and ſo Good night to you, Gallants.

div.stage: Exit Daſhit and his Wife, as into their houſe.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Well, dear Jack, Good night: I have a Viſit to make before I ſleep, and will take my leave o' thee. A found Wench, ſoft Sleep, and pleaſant Dreams, bleſs thee, my dear Friendly.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Not ſo, I'll ſee thee ſafe at home; I dare not leave ye to your ſelf ſo late; you are warm with Youth and Wine, which may direct you to the undoing of that body of yours which ſhortly muſt be bleſt with chaſt embraces. Theſe common women will ruine thee, Frank; Faith leave 'em in good time: come, you ſhall not to a Bawdy-houſe, I hate 'em.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I pray for their continuance and increaſe ere ſince I thought of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prithee why?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: A married man ought to love a Bawdy-houſe, as Engliſh-men love Flanders; wiſh war ſhou'd be maintain'd there, leſt it ſhou'd be brought home to their own doors.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thou art a worthy Lad, and brave; but this damn'd Luſt has been thy conſtant daily vice, the onely one thou'rt given to.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Prithee call it a nightly one: But not to trifle with thee, Faith I am going the way of all fleſh.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: To a Whore?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: One thou calleſt ſo, a very Publican and ſinner.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
And canſt thou, having ſuch an Object before thy eyes as the fair, the chaſt Mirinda, whom thou'rt to marry, give thy ſelf up to the looſe, the common arms of one who loves thee not but for her intereſt? Damn her, thou ſhalt not go. I hate, I
nauſeate a common Proſtitute, who trades with all for gain; one that ſells humane fleſh, a Mangoniſt.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Poor Devils, what wou'd you have 'em do? wou'dſt thou have 'em get their living by the Curſe of man, the Sweat of their Brows? Egad they dearly earn what we give 'em. Is Charitie grown a ſin, or relieving the Poor and Impotent, an offence? And Faith, Franck, where can we beſtow our Money better? In Land the Title may be crackt, in Houſes they may be burnt, in fine Cloaths they'll wear out, in Wine, alas, our Throats are but ſhort, and our heads weak; but woman, oh dear lovely woman's the laſting true pleaſure! Lay it out upon woman, I ſay, and a thouſand to one, ſome one of them will beſtow that on you that ſhall ſtick by you as long as you live: They are no ungrateful perſons, they'll give Love for Love; do you proteſt, they'll ſwear; do you vow, they'll lye; do you ſigh, they'll weep; do you give them Engliſh Coin, they'll repay you with the French—And they onely ſell their Bodies: Do not ſome of our Sex ſell their Souls? nay, ſince all things have been ſold, Honour, Juſtice, Faith, even Religion, pray where's the diſhonour of ſelling the Pleaſures of a womans Bed? Who is't wou'd live and toil, but for a woman? who fights, lies cold and hard in open field, but to gain Wreaths to lay at a womans feet?
And 'tis a truth can be denied of no man:
All things were made for man, and man for woman.
—Give me my Fee.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I ſee you are reſolv'd, and I can onely boaſt I love Diana better than you do her Siſter Marinda.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Come, wilt thou go with me?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: To this houſe of Salvation.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Salvation!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Yes, 'twill make thee repent. Prithee go to the Family of Love, I'll ſhew thee my Creature, my Natural, my Miſtriſs, my pretty blue-ey'd Wanton, my honeſt fond ſelf-hearted Flatterer, my fair-fac'd, ſweet lip'd Rogue, that has Beauty enough for her Vertue, Vertue enough for a Woman, and Woman enough for any reaſonable man, in my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What to a Bawdy-houſe, to viſit an impudent Proſtitute? Pox on't, 'twill make me hate the Sex. The worſt Object the world can ſhew me, is an immodeſt vulgar woman.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: No matter, thou ſhalt go; go as thou loveſt me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I'll go to bring you ſafely back.

div.head: SCENE draws to a Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Dunwell, and Trickwell drunk.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Nay, Moll, unreaſonable Mary! whe, the whole Prize was not above fortie pound; and haſt thou the conſcience to ſnack ten onely for a good word ſpeaking, a little holding the door, and bawding? The device was my own too, the hazard mine, and the hanging may be mine, whilſt thou ſecurely filcheſt under my conduct. Come, the neſt of Cups is fair, you Bitch, be contented; you were drunk too into the bargain, Moll. Come, bear a Conſcience, Moll, and Heaven will bleſs our endeavours: beſides, Moll, thou haſt an honeſt Calling of Bawding, which brings thee in a pretty Livelihood, Moll; when God knows I truſt to nothing but my own indurious ſlight of hand. Come, give me back the Salt.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: By Yea and by Nay, Trickwell, I am afraid thou wilt play the Knave, and reſtore 'em.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No, by the Lord, Aunt, Reſtitution is Catholick; and you know Oracles are ceas'd. Tempus praeteritum.—Doſt hear, my neceſſary Evil?—Thou ungodly Fire that burnt Diana's Temple, doſt hear? make Corina civil, or by the Lord, Bawd—

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Fire! Gad you are the fouleſt mouth'd ſon of a Whore, the profaneſt railing Raſkal, call a woman the moſt ungodly names! I muſt confeſs we all eat of the forbidden Fruit; and for my own part, though I am, as they ſay, a Bawd that covers a multitude of ſins, yet I truſt I am none of the wicked that go to Steeple-houſes with profane Organs in 'em, ye ſcurvy ſawcie Jack.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Who, I rail at thee, my induſtrious Moll, my ſubtle Procurer? I rail at thee, my neceſſarie Damnation? I'll make an Oration in praiſe of thy Modeſtie, thou flower of thy Function.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: And I think I have deſerv'd it at your hands, Mr. Trickwell; for I have aſſiſted you early and late, up-riſing, and downlying.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
Thou haſt; therefore liſten: A Bawd for her Profeſſion is the moſt honourable of all the 12 Companies; for as that Trade
is moſt worſhipful that ſells the beſt Commodities, what muſt the Bawd be then, my little Moll? For where others ſell ſilk Cloaths, Gold and Silver, Pearls and Diamonds, thou ſelleſt divine Vertue, Virginitie, Modeſtie, Maiden-heads, Youth and Beautie: And who are her Cuſtomers? not Cits, Grooms, Mechanicks, and diſbanded Souldiers; but Gentlemen of the beſt Rank, Knights, Lords, Dukes, and Squires. Thus ſhe lives, keeps the beſt Company, eats and drinks of the beſt, and domineers when ſhe's drunk, reigns Queen, Moll, over her adoring Subjects. But hold, here's Wellman and Friendly! what a Pox does his Gravitie in a Bawdie-houſe?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Come along, yonders the Preface to my Miſtriſs, her Matron, or Bawd, or what you pleaſe. Mrs. Dunwell, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Your ſervant, ſweet Sir: Ah, you're a prettie man, to neglect a Creature that loves you thus; introth you are—But well, I'll fetch her to you, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Do ſo, ſweet Mrs. Dunwell.—What, Mr. Trickwell, does your Knaveſhip dare walk the ſtreet? Look to't, Mr. Daſhit lies in wait for you.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The more fool he; I can lie for my ſelf: A Pox of the rich Raſkal, 'tis no deceit in me to cheat him; he has cozen'd me of an Eſtate of ſome two hundred a year, with his damn'd Reckonings, and then who but honourable Mr. Trickwell, the noble Squire, and ſoforth, till he had got all my Land in Mortgage; then took the forfeiture, and turn'd me 〈◊〉 of doors. I'll plague him for't. But I interrupt your diverſion, and will kiſs your hands, my noble Patrons.

div.stage: Enter Dunwell and Corina, ſhe kicking her.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: See, Sir, this the ugly thing you ſo deſpiſe!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: This very thing: 'tis but a Dowdie—but ſhe ſerves.—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A Whore this! Vertue defend me, what a lovely woman 'tis!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Salute her, man, ſalute her.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Salute her! yes, and leave my heart upon her lips.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Go, ſalute my friend; this is my friend Corina.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
I care not for you nor your friends; I'm ſure you uſe me ſcurvily, becauſe you know I love you: but I ſhall learn thoſe
Arts you men are practis'd in; and ſcorn, and hate, and hide it, when it ſerves my turn, as you can do.—I ſhall—but yet I'm true, true as my Vertue when you firſt ſeduc'd it, falſe as you are,—and yet I love you ſtrangely.—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Salute my friend, I ſay—go, you fond fool, claſp his neck round, and preſs his cheeks to yours; kiſs him as you do me, as ſoft and meltingly: go, you coy tit, I ſay you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: She'as fir'd me with that touch:—there's Witchcraft in't.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Come, kiſs her again; by Heaven thou ſhalt, I'll not be jealous on't: kiſs her more ardently—So, thou wilt learn in time. Go fetch your Lute, and let him hear ye ſing to't.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I'm all obedience, Sir, when you command; but I have ſomething heavie at my heart that makes me wiſh you wou'd excuſe me now.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Go too, I ſay—what can ſit heavie there? I love thee, love thee infinitly, in faith I do, Corina. Here, here's Gold for thee; the Summer's coming on, and thou perhaps wants Toys, as Gowns and Points, and Petticoats. I'll have thee ſhow, Corina, with the beſt, ſplendid and gay, my Girl, as is thy Beauty.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I'll take this Gold, but 'tis not that I want: methinks of late there is a ſtrange decay of Paſſion in you; you're not ſo dearly fond as you were wont, ſupplying ſtill your want of Love with Gold; your Mirth is forc'd, your Viſits cold and ſhort, as Winterdays; and when you ſpeak of Love, you do't with caution. There's ſome reſerve hid in that generous breaſt, which I wou'd be acquainted with, yet tremble leſt you ſhou'd betray't too ſoon.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Corina, you miſtake my heart, 'tis thine, intirely thine; but when a Lover's ſure, as I am of thy heart, thoſe little aſſiduities are neglected which onely hoping Lovers uſe to pay. I am happie now, and have no need of Vows but thoſe of Conſtancie. Go to your Lute.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And have ye none you do deſigne to marry?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p:
Fie, you're a fool to think I be ſo weak; Marry! I ſcorn that ſlaverie, whilſt I poſſeſs all the delights of it with thee, without its plagues and care.—Go to your Lute. [Exit Cor.] Well, Frank, and how doſt thou like my Miſtriſs? is ſhe not charming? do you blame me now? Introth I lov'd her dearly once, till my Soul ſhew'd me the imperfections of my bodie, and plac'd my
love on a more worthy object, my fair Marinda; which if this Baggage knew, there were no being for me, ſhe wou'd ſo rave: But faith I think I'm not ſo criminal as you imagin'd, hah?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Yet ſhe's a Whore!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: A Whore! Oh call her a Miſs, a Ladie of the Town, a Beautie of delight, or any thing. Whore! 'tis a nauſeous name, and out of faſhion now to call things by their right names. Is a Citizen a Cuckold? no, he's one of the Liverie: Is a great man a Fool? no, he's weak, or led away: Is a Perſon of Qualitie pockie? no, but is not well, has got a Surfeit, or ſo. Come, ſhe is a Miſtriſs,—but heark, ſhe ſings!

div.stage: A Song within to a Lute, after which, enters Corina.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: She's all a perfect Heaven! Oh I adore her!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: To obey your commands, I ſung, my Love, but I had rather you had pardon'd me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: You are a ſimple Chit; go, get you gone, and let me go; 'tis late, and I am ſleepie.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: This Language was not wont to come from thee; take heed, and do not cheat my eaſie Faith: for if you do, perhaps 'twill make me mad; and in my wildneſs ſome ſtrange things may do, may ruine both our lives. Take heed; for now I love ye much above 'em both. Come, you ſhall ſtay with me to night.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: By no means, my Dear; this Gentleman has vow'd to ſee me chaſtly laid.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And ſo ye ſhall: the Play of Infants ſhall not be more chaſt. I have no wiſh to make him break his Vow, and he ſhall have a Bed.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Peace! that offer will offend him; he's a modeſt man, one of a profeſt abſtinence. Good night.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And muſt you go?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I muſt.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And will you come to morrow? But oh I did not uſe to aſk ſuch Queſtions. Will you be ſure?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I will: when did I fail? Good night. Boy, your Flambeau. Good night, Corina.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Why ſtay you, Sir? you ſee your friend is gone.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Madam, if he knows not how to prize Heaven, I do; and cannot leave the pleaſure ſo ſoon, at leaſt if you wou'd give me leave to gaze, I dare not ſay poſſeſs, that were a bleſſing fit
onely for the Gods; nor knows man how to calm it.—That you ſhou'd throw away ſuch wonderous beautie on the remiſs, cold, and inſenſible!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Who is it, Sir, that's ſo inſenſible?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Death, whither does my paſſion hurry me? I ſhall betray friendſhip of many years, for a flame which a new luſt has kindled in a moment.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Heavens! are you ſilent, Sir? what made ye talk of one remiſs and cold? who mean ye? Wellman? Oh, if you did—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I meant mankinde; for none can merit you.—Is ſhe unchaſt? can ſuch an one be damn'd? Oh Love and Beautie, you two eldeſt ſeeds of the vaſt Chaos, what ſtrong right ye have even in things divine, our very Souls!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Why do you ſtifle what was ſo well begun? Unfold; I know you have ſome meaning, Sir, in what you have to ſay: Concerns it Wellman?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No. Anſwer me one thing, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I will: for you have ſomething to relate, which I muſt hear. Demand; I liſten.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: The Queſtion is but rude.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I care not.—What means he?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Are you—You pardon me?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I do. There's ſomething in his heart that I muſt flatter thence. Be confident.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And are you then—a—Whore? You ſaid you wou'd forgive.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I did: and though that queſtion, yet 'cauſe I know thou haſt ſome reaſon for't, I'll anſwer thee directly, That I am.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Are Proſtitutes ſuch things, ſo delicate? Can cuſtom ſpoil what Nature made ſo good? I never ſaw a ſweet face vitious: it might be proud, inconſtant, wanton, vain.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh leave, Sir, to philoſophize on Beautie, and tell me why you do ſo.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Heavens! why cou'dſt not thou be conſtant?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Conſtant! to what? to whom?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: To Wellman: he has all the Charms of Nature; and to be falſe to him, was ſuch a ſin—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
Oh Heavens! what baſe flatterer has traduc'd me? tell me; who dares report I am not true, not true to Wellman? I have been falſe to Vertue, falſe to Honour, falſe to my Name and
Friends; but was to Wellman what Heaven is to the Juſt and Penitent, all ſoft, all mercie, all complying ſweetneſs.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: By Heaven, I do believe it; and nere heard a breath that cou'd prophanely ſay thou wert not: But oh, I thought with reaſon, if 'twere ſo, I cou'd not ſlightly part with ſuch a Jewel, or, Indian-like, barter this real Gold for ſhining gingling Bawbles. Marinda! Heaven, thou'rt an Angel to her!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Enough: I know my doom; that word's enough; and I'm betray'd to ruine! [aſide.] I will: My heart, thou ſhalt diſſemble this—Go, baſe falſe man, that with the name of Friend has play'd the Traytor to the beſt of men. I know thou injur'ſt Wellman; or if true, 'twas not thy part to tell it: hadſt thou licenſe for ſuch a cruel Tale, thou ſhou'dſt have ſpar'd it to her that lov'd thy friend. Be gone, I hate thee, and whatſoere thou meants by ſuch a Lye, I ſcorn thee for't, and think thee much unfit for any gallant friendſhip: I know 'tis truth, and with the fatal knowledge inſtruct my heart to break.

div.stage: Friendly muſing alone, enter peeping Wellman.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Tho I do not care for this woman now, yet ſome dregs of the old haunt of Jealouſie remain about me ſtill; and I muſt ſee what uſe my friend and quondam Miſtriſs makes of this kinde opportunitie.—Hah! alone, and muſing!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Twas not well done, indeed, to tell her; but Love was raging in me, and I believ'd I ſhou'd inſinuate with that ſecret.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: By Heaven, he's caught! Eternal Laughter ſeize me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Twas Love! the very firſt effects of Love were treacherous and ill: Heaven guard me from the reſt. Yet I muſt on:
Let Winter'd Age dully pretend to prove
That Love is Luſt; I know no life but Love.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Is it ſo, Sweet-heart? how is't? what, is the worſt ſight the world can produce, a common woman now?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Hah! will you go home, Sir? 'tis high bed-time.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir; onely do not chide me. I muſt confeſs.—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A wanton Lover you have been.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: When Love was raging in me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Oh leave your rallying; will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p:
Let Winter'd Age dully pretend to prove That Love is Luſt; I know no life but Love.
Go thy ways for an Apoſtate; I believe my laſt Garment muſt be let out in the ſeams for you: Is't not ſo? But come, I muſt go ſerinade Marinda; but take this certain rule along with thee:
Of all the Fools that Ignorance ere nurſt,
He that 'gainſt Nature wou'd be wiſe, is worſt.

div.head: SCENE the Second.
div.stage: Enter Wellman and Friendly, with Footmen with Lights, and men with Muſick; as under Marinda's Window.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: WEll, Gentlemen, here's the Window of my dear Marinda: 'tis here, my friends, reſides that lovely Maid, whoſe beautie chaces away thoſe leſſer fires that did infeſt my heart. Come, gently touch your ſtrings, and call her forth to bleſs me ere I go to reſt: I'm not half ſanctifi'd without a ſight.

div.stage: They play a little, then a Song.
Enter Marinda above, in Night-dreſs, and Diana.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Who's there, my dear lov'd Wellman? This was kinde.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: My generous Marinda! when did I ere approach thee but with kindneſs, the fondeſt tendereſt part of kindneſs too? and when I ceaſe to do ſo, Heaven neglect me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And me, when I but fear the contrary. Wou'd I cou'd let thee in; but oh I dare not: my Father nicely careful, tho thou'rt mine, mine by a ſolemn Contract, yet forbids me to entertain thee with that freedom yet.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: But, my Marinda, 'tis a heavenly night, ſuch as was made for Lovers, ſtill and calm; and I have ſuch ſoft things to whiſper to thee, as pains me to conceal. I long to touch thy hand, to catch thy ſighs, and lean my head upon thy riſing boſome. A freedom now methinks you might allow me: 'tis very hard.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo; but yet a little ſuffering, and we may meet with lawful freedom: till when, continue to be true and kinde.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: By Heaven, by all the Stars that ſhine above, and by thy brighter Eyes, I will be ever true.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I muſt give faith to what you ſay; and prithee ſince,
eaſie Maid, I do believe ſo ſoon, in pitie do not cheat me. Here, wear this little Ring; a dying Brother gave it, and bad me never part with it but to him that Love had made my Huſband: Wear it thou; for thou'rt my Souls beſt choice.

div.stage: Takes it in his hand, and kiſſes it.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Which when I part from, Hope, the beſt comfort of my life, forſake me.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Heavens! what a long tedious Tale of Faith and Troth's here! Cou'd I once ſee the man I lik'd, I'd have done a thouſand fine and more material things by this time.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Madam, here is a Man, whom if you cou'd but pity—

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: What, my grave Lover Mr. Friendly, who hates a Wencher! no by my Troth, I'm for no ſuch dull Ingredience in a Lover: I love a man that knows the way to a womans bed without inſtructions. Beſides, what ſhou'd we two do together, get Fools? no, I hate 'em.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: You may be miſtaken in your man.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: I wiſh I were: Let him but bring it under the hand of any woman who has been kinde to him, and I'll believe him fit to be belov'd by me; till then, I am obdurate.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I'll endeavour to obey you.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Let it be quickly then, I hate delays, you know I'm ſtor'd with Lovers, Sir John Empty will be before-hand with you elſe; you know he's a ſpruce Spark, and cannot long lay ſiege before a heart, but he will force an entrance: he's of my humour too, gay, loves Fiddles, Wine and Women; a fool and rich, oh heavenly Quality! Be wiſe, Sir, and conſider 'em, and learn to whore betimes; you know not what you may come to. Farewel, the day begins to break, and the old man will wake. Good morrow, modeſt Mr. Friendly.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Good morrow, mad-cap: Come, ſhall's go to bed?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, I cannot ſleep; I'll walk a little.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: And meditate? Farewel, Sir, I'm for reſt.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
This woman yeſterday was charming to me, and now all that ſhe ſaid, ſeem'd dull and tedious. What a ſtrange change is here! The light comes on; heark how the free-born Birds chant forth their untaught Paſſions, and in thoſe pretty Notes expreſs their love. They have no Bawds, no mercenary Beds, no politick Reſtraints, no artful Heats, no faint Diſſemblings; Cuſtom makes them not bluſh, nor Sham afflicts their name. Oh happy
Birds, in whom an inborn heat is held no ſin! how vaſtly you tranſcend poor wretched man, whom national cuſtom, tyrannous reſpect of ſlaviſh order fetters, calling that ſin in us, which in all elſe is Nature's higheſt Vertue. But a Whore! now ſhame forſake me, whither am I fallen, one that my friend has had, to live to be a ſhameful talk to men!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I have a mind to know whether Friendly goes to Corina; when I am abſent, 'tis with ſome regret I think he ſhou'd; but preſent, it ſo pleaſes me to ſee his modeſty in love, I'm ready to reſigne her.—He's here ſtill! Good morrow, Friend, I cannot leave thee thus diſſatisfi'd; what art thou ſtudying on?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Love; but it likes me not.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: She is not honeſt.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: What then? ſhou'd we hate all that are ſo, ſome men wou'd hate their Mothers and their Siſters; a ſin againſt kind.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Is it a wiſe man's part to be in love?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Let wiſe men alone; 'twill beſeem thee and me well enough.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And ſhall I not commit a ſin againſt friendſhip?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: What to love where I do? By Heaven, I reſigne her freely to thee: the creature and I muſt grow ſtrangers; and by this time ſhe has heard of my deſigne to marry, and ſwears and rails, and cries, and curſes me. Come, faith I will reſigne her, and you ſee Diana will like thee nere the worſe for't.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I'll but embrace her, hear her ſpeak, and at the moſt but kiſs her.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Oh heark, he that cou'd live upon the ſcent of Meat, wou'd live cheaply.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I ſhall never become heartily a man o'th' Town, a kind of flat ungracious Debauchee; an unſufficient dulneſs reigns about me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: This Italian breeding has ſpoil'd thee, and ſtiffen'd thy behaviour. Come, come, thou ſhalt to her, and ſhe ſhall like thee.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But if ſhe ſhou'd not, Friend!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Fear her not, 'tis her Trade, and what ſhe'as practis'd long with many Lovers.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Was ſhe not true to thee?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I do believe ſhe was, whilſt ſhe was mine.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Was ſhe a ſinner ere you ſaw her then?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Oh a very Strumpet! Pardon me truth. Come, have a good heart, and thou ſhalt poſſeſs her, ſince thou'rt ſo in love.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Death, man, 'tis Deſtiny, I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Nay, I hope ſo. Come, come, ſhe ſells but fleſh; ſo that even in the enjoying thou't regain again thy freedom. Go thy ways. [Exit Friend. Enter Trickwell.] How now, Raſkal! what make you up ſo early?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He that will thrive, muſt be early ſtirring, Sir: I am going to get the Peny, Sir; Aye, Heaven has endow'd me with induſtry, I thank it.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: And what good Acquaintance have you, Sirrah? no handſome women?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, yes, ſome do ſtart up now and then; but a Pox on't, when they have run through all the Trades and Degrees of the Citie, they paſs at the other ſide of the Town for new Faces, and are caught up by your Courtiers for innocent and honeſt, though the Citie-Surgeon have had good Cuſtomers of 'um; and by my Troth, Sir, I hate to cheat a Gentleman with falſe Ware. But laſt night—

sp.speaker: VVell.
sp.p: What laſt night?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I was horrid drunk at Supper with one Sir John Empty, a brave young fool for my purpoſe; I brought him a Wench, one Betty Cogit; a Pox on her, a pretty drunken Whore 'tis, and handſome: if ſhe can ſerve you, I can bed my Knight with any other.

sp.speaker: VVell.
sp.p: Away, you're a Rogue; I'll talk about it another time. Farewel: Have a care of Mr. Daſhit, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Let Mr. Daſhit have a care of me; I'll take care he ſhall be cozen'd moſt plentifully. Now for ſome new device! what ſhall it be?

div.stage: Enter Jack, a boy with Barbers things.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, which is the way to Cheapſide, to the Sun-Tavern?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sun-Tavern, Childe! what wou'dſt thou do there?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Whe, Sir, I am ſent for to trim Mr. Daſhit; and tho he be my God-father, I know not the way to his houſe.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Why, art thou a Barber?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: A Barber-Surgeon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: To what Bawdy-houſe does your Maſter belong? and what's your name?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: John Scowre, an't like your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: John Scowre! Good Mr. John Scowre, I deſire your farther acquaintance. Nay, be cover'd, my dainty boy. Is thy Maſter at home?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: My Father, forſooth, you mean; but he's dead.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And laid in's Grave, good boy?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and my Mother keeps ſhop.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: A good witty boy; thon't live to read a Chapter to the Family, and write Sermons, John, in time, wo't thou▪ not?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: In grace a God, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And whither art thou going now, John?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Marry, forſooth, to trim Mr. Daſhit the Vintner, He's my Godfather, I told you, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Good boy, hold up thy head. Prithee do one thing for me; my name's Hazard.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: He! good Mr. Hazard!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Lend me thy Barbers Implements.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Sir!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well ſpoken, a fine boy! What are they worth, childe?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Sir, worth! I know not.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: A witty childe! Here's a ſhilling for thee. Where doſt live, John?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: At the three Waſhballs, forſooth, in Mincing-lane.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Aye, I know't; a delicate boy! I have an odde Jeſt in my head, childe, to trim Mr. Daſhit: 'Tis for a wager, boy, a humour; I'll return thy things preſently. Hold, let's ſee—

div.stage: Takes off his Apron, and takes his things.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: What mean ye, Mr. Hazard?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Nothing, child, but a Jeſt. Go drink a flaggon, and I'll return preſently.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, do not ſtay.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: As I'm an honeſt man—The three Waſhbals, John?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Aye, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Good: And if I do not ſhave Mr. Daſhit, my ingenaity wants an edge. Let me ſee, a Barber! My villanous tongue will betray me; I muſt ſtep in and diſguiſe a little. For my ſpeech, what if it be broken French, or a Northern or a Welch Barber? Good, the Widow Scowres man: good, newly hir'd a Journeyman; very well: I have my Cue, and will proceed, happy be luck—

div.head: SCENE changes to Corina's houſe.
div.stage: Enter Corina with her Hair looſe, raving, and Mr. Dunwell.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Nay, dear ſweet childe, do not torment thy ſelf thus violently: ſay Wellman be to be marri'd, are there no more young Gentlemen, no more both handſome and rich? Come, come, you cou'd not expect to build Tabernacles with him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Damn your ſententious Nonſence, let me go looſe as the winds when mad, when raging mad. 'Twas you, Heaven curſe ye for't, that firſt ſeduc'd me, ſwore that he lov'd me, wou'd eternally; and when my Vertue had reſolv'd me good, damn'd Witch, whoſe trade is Lying and Confuſion, you hard beſieg'd it round with tales of Wellman, repeated all his Charms ſo often o're, my Heart began to yield, and Vertue fade like flowers with too much heat; which when you ſaw; a Curſe upon your Tongue, you told him where the part was feebleſt here—told him my ſtrength, and how he beſt might conquer: and he, oh lovely Tyrant, found it true, and never ceas'd till he had vanquiſht all. Leave me, thou Witch, that haſt reduc'd this ſoul, this body too, to nothing but a Grave.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: To nothing! Marry and that's not my fault; I have made as many proffers of your Virginity ſince he ruin'd it, as if you had been my own Daughter a thouſand times, ſo I have; but you were ſo peeviſh, you ever ſtood in your own light; nothing wou'd down with you but Wellman.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Hell take thy tongue, or blaſt it.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Aye, for God forgive me, it has been a thouſand times forſworn for you, and yet I've brought you to nothing. Have I not brought you Engliſh and French Merchants of the beſt Rank, Jews of the richeſt Tribes, Iriſh Lords, Scottiſh Earls, and laſtly, the Dutch Agent, who offer'd ye a Tun of money? and is all this nothing? Come, come, had you had grace, you had made ſomething of all theſe; but nothing but Wellman was regarded.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh that hated Name, like ſome black Charm it curdles up my bloud.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: And yet, a'my conſcience the Gentleman's an honeſt Gentleman, and one you have got fairly by; I hope him to you, and have I this for my labour? Well, Mary Dunwell, [weeps] go thy ways; Mary Dunwell, thy kinde heart will bring thee to the Hoſpital.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I'll be reveng'd; nothing but dire Revenge ſhall ſatiate my Rage. Methinks I am inſpir'd with manly ſtrength, a bloudy courage ſwells my riſing heart, and I ſhall act ſome wonderous diſmal miſchief. And yet to ſee him bleed, he that has ſworn ſo many tender things, and breath'd 'em all in kiſſes on my boſome; but now all thoſe, and thouſands new invented, he pays another Miſtriſs more beloved. I die, I die, and cannot bear that thought, by which I finde I'm feeble woman ſtill. Why didſt thou? tell me, for I'll here begin, why didſt thou praiſe this Monſter?—To my ſoul.

div.stage: Draws a Dagger and takes hold of her.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Heavens, Madam, hold and hear me: I did praiſe him, I confeſs; I ſaid he was a fool, a laviſh fool, one that lov'd women more than his Religion, that he kept high, and lov'd moſt ardently: but what of this? the wind you ſee is turn'd.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Turn all then to confuſion; turn, thou Witch, 'tis I will play the Devil. Heart, reſolve, and ſet down this decree, never to reſt till thou haſt made him equal to me, wretched.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Madam, Mr. Wellman and Mr. Friendly are below, and deſire leave to kiſs your hand.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh he's grown ceremonious in his Viſits. No more, I will be calm, as if my fortune knew no change; I will diſſemble, ſmile;
I'll ſhew my ſelf all woman in my Art, Puts the Dagger and Piſtol in her two Pockets.
But be a very Devil in my heart.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: How now Corina, what diſorder's this?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh my dear life! this woman has diſpleas'd me; but one kinde look from thee chaſes all other thoughts out of my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: But what's the matter? do not diſſemble with me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: With thee! far be ſuch art from thy Corina's tongue; you've taught her truth with love. What elſe ſhou'd ſuch a Maſter teach a Miſtriſs? Come, I forgive her now: Alas, ſhe'as loſt the little Dog you gave me. Wou'd it not grieve one to looſe ought of thine?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Fie, fie, cry for a Dog! what wou'dſt thou do for me that pay'ſt ſuch tributes to a poor worthleſs Animal?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: For thee, weep tears of bloud; but 'tis impoſſible I cou'd be robb'd of thee by ought but death. I know thy noble heart—to be a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Thou art ſo fond, thou mind'ſt nothing but me; ſees thou not my friend?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes, and love him too, next to thy ſelf, by Heaven; for he's as great a Villain, being he's man. Come, Sir, you muſt not be ſo ſad; I'll ſing and dance, do any thing to make you gay and ſmile: for truſt me, Sir, I hate ſad Company. Heavens, what ails you, Sir? have you the Tooth-ach, Sir? I've many remedies for that.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, my pain is at my heart; have you a Cure for that?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A thouſand. Kinde Eyes, ſoft Sighs and Kiſſes well appli'd.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Twill but increaſe the pain: 'twas ſo I caught it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Alas, I'll ſing then; I have a thouſand Songs, ſo pretty and ſo loving.—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Still that but hurts me more.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Then I've no Remedies. [ſighs.] Hah, what Ring is that? I like it, and muſt have it.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: No you muſt not, Love.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Fie, you call me Love, and cry I muſt not! I ſay I will. How now, who is't commands where I am?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: You intirely; but this Ring I cannot part with.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 'Tis my Rivals: Rot with his finger, how it fires my bloud, and the red flame kindles about my face, and will betray my heart! Come, 'tis a trifle.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I care not for the value.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Has it a worth beſides its own intrinſick one?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Nay, you're of late ſo peeviſh and ſo jealous, that you grow troubleſome.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Jealous! by this dear mouth not I. [Kiſſes him.] Come, give me the Ring; by all that's kinde, you ſhall: By all our Loves, and by all thoſe ſoft Embraces when in my Arms you ſwore eternal Love, eternal Faith, I do conjure ye give it me: I never us'd to beg ſuch Toys in vain.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Thou art uncivilly importunate. Go, fool, thou ſha't not ha't; I care not for thee nor thy Jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
He ſpeaks his ſoul in that, which from his mouth deſtroys all my diſſembling. I know that Ring, thou falſer than the Devil; I know it is Marinda's, your new Miſtriſs: tak • her, but take her far from me be ſure; keep her as thou wou'dſt ſecrets that wou'd damn thee; for if ſhe take but Air, ſhe is no more; it
will be all infected with my Sighs and Curſes, and 'twill be catching, Sir: look to't, it will.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Thou'rt grown a hectoring Whore!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Leave me, or ſuch another word from thee will put thee into danger. Dar'ſt thou upbraid the faults thou haſt created? Furies poſſeſs me, that I may incounter the like Fate or killing Blaſts! Oh I cou'd rave to think I want that power that might deſtroy thee!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Do not turn Witch before thy time, Corina.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I wou'd I were, that I might be an age in damning thee: But words are Air that blow above thy head, and cannot wound nor blaſt.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Nay, if you rave, I'll leave ye; fare ye well.—You will not go.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And is it true, haſt thou abandon'd me? Canſt thou forget our numerous Bliſſes paſt, the hours we've waſted out in Tales of Love, and curſt all interruption but of Kiſſes, which 'twixt thy charming words I ever gave thee; when the whole live-long day we thought too ſhort, yet bleſt the coming night? Haſt thou forgot, falſe are thy Vows, all perjur'd, and thy Faith broken as my poor loſt forſaken heart? and wou'dſt thou wiſh me live to ſee this Change! Cou'dſt thou believe, if thou hadſt hid it from the talking world, my heart cou'd not have found it out by ſympathie! A fooliſh unconſidering faithleſs man!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: This is as troubleſome as Rage to me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Some comfort that thou doſt confeſs thou'rt baſe; and this laſt blaze of my departing Love, has but a minutes light, and now 'tis gone.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: It went in fume, and leaves a ſcent behinde it which does offend my ſenſe: Farewel.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Farewel. And doſt thou think I'll part with thee thus tamely! Faithleſs unthinking fool, by Heaven, no other woman ſhall poſſeſs thee; the perjur'd heart you gave, thus I demand: [Takes a Piſtol out of her pocket, fires it at his breaſt; it onely flaſhes in the pan: Friendly runs to her; ſhe throws it away.] Oh damn this treacherous inſtrument, falſe as the heart 'twas aim'd at: But ſince, like Coward States, I wanted courage to attack the Foe, I'll turn my Fury into civil Broyls, and hurl all to confuſion here within.

div.stage: [Offers to ſtab her ſelf; Friendly runs to her, prevents her, and ſhe ſeems fainted a little while in his arms.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Pray leave her, Sir, your preſence but inflames her.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I will: look to her, prithee. I was too raſh, and miſt from too much violence and rage—I might have more ſecurely done the buſineſs. [aſide.] Pray leave me, Sir, I cannot go, a fire in my blood confines me here: 'Tis not a vertuous flame!
No, raging Luſt my wilful fate does move;
The Gods themſelves cannot be wiſe and love.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: This man whom I abhor becauſe his Friend, through all my rage, I ſee has paſſion for me, raiſe it, ye Powers, till it become ſo high to be employ'd to any uſe, I'll put it to a fatal inſtrument of my Revenge. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Lovelieſt of all your injur'd Sex.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You're charitable to the forſaken, Sir, but 'tis alas all thrown away on me; for I can never more believe there can be honeſty in man, ſince Wellman is all Vice.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What Devil, envious of his glorious Choice, contriv'd to make him faithleſs to ſuch Beauty! Had I that Bleſſing, which I dare not name, hardly dare wiſh, 'tis ſo above my merit, I ſhou'd diſpiſe, as uſeleſs and unneceſſary, all the vaſt Joys beſides Heaven has in ſtore, and at thy feet lay all my Fortunes down, and ſet up my eternal reſt with thee.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Juſt ſo he ſpoke, and I fond fool believ'd, and tir'd him out with love; but you're all falſe, inconſtant, faithleſs Tyrants, and betrayers even in that very minute that you gain us; we forfeit all our hopes in you for ever. I can believe no more.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Silence and Modeſtie were wont to be my two accuſtom'd Vertues; but my Love grows high and rages in me like a ſtorm: Wou'd you'd believe my Vows; but you have been deceiv'd that way alreadie: therefore, thou dear, thou lovely injur'd fair one, credit my plain Sinceritie. I love, and to be ſhort, wou'd have thee pay my flame, I will be grateful in what way you pleaſe. Take me to your Embraces, to your Bed. I am not us'd to aſk ſuch Queſtions, Madam, and want terms fit to dreſs 'em in.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And do you take me then for ſuch a Creature, that have no ſenſe but Appetite, the Brutal part of Love? Forbear to name it to me, you offend me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Forgive me; I wou'd have you love me too: and if I have too haſtily run o're what ought to have been ſaid of my vaſt Paſſion, and came too rudely on the wiſht-for part, 'tis the effects
of youthful ignorance, of hot deſire, and eager to be happy.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: How ſhall I fain to yield! [aſide?] There's ſuch a ſeeming honeſt plainneſs, Sir, in what you ſay, in ſpight of all my grief, I liſten to your Language. Cou'd you be true, cou'd you convince me throughly that you lov'd!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: [kneeling.] What Art will do't? what Vows, what Proteſtations, what Proofs, what Gifts, beſides a faithful Heart?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Shall I, or can I truſt again? Oh fool, how natural 'tis for women to believe! But when you've gain'd the utmoſt that you aſk, will you not then grow cold?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: As ſoon the Sun ſhall loſe its native heat, denying warmth to Flowers.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I muſt have more than this: Can you believe this heart that has been us'd ſo ill already, can you truſt on feeble Vows? Can you be bravely kinde, reſolve a Deed wou'd ſhake a Soul that is not fixt in Love?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Is it a Deed that I may do with honour?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I did not ſtudie that; but if there be any thing that ſtands in competition with your Love, it is not worth my owning.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Be it what it will, 'tis for ſo rich a Prize, without demanding what, I'll vow it done.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I hate this Wellman: You may gueſs the reſt. Good day to you.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Leaving me! by Heaven we muſt not part: Love and Deſire are madly raving in me; my impatient Heat admits of no reſiſtance: I cannot-live, without you grant me inſtantly that which I dare not aſk.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: As long as Wellman lives, I've made a Vow never to love again; yet am I underſtood.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Will you be mine when Wellman is no more?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: By all my hopes, by my laſt beſt of wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Be mine, and onely mine, for ever mine?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Inviolably yours.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Then hear me, on my knees I make this Vow: Wellman ſhall die before to morrows light. Now may I hope my Bliſs?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes, when the Deed is done. And for a Token that you have diſpatcht him, bring me that Diamond that he wears, and which he did refuſe me.—Do you pawſe—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Onely the manner, Sweet—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh you may pick a ſudden Quarrel with him, word it to blows, and then take all advantages.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And will my Vows to kill him, merit nothing?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No, I have vow'd, and if you love, you'l yield to't.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Enough: Farewel. She goes out.

Delays in Love's the Lovers onely Hell. Going out haſtily ſtops. Hah! whither wou'd my haſtie ſteps miſguide me! was I not ruſhing on to kill a Friend? to kill a Friend, oh 'tis to kill my ſelf! Paſſion, how helliſh art thou? oh how vile, to kill a Friend to gain a ſinful woman for Appetite, for ſenſual end, and momentarie pleaſure;
And Vices like to ſwelling Rivers flow,
The further that they run they bigger grow.
Heaven! how neer was I to being undone! I'll flie, leſt the temptation overtake me.

div.head: SCENE changes to Daſhit's houſe.

sp.speaker: Enter Mrs.
sp.p: Daſhit with a bag of money, Mr. Daſhit following.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Well, is the money right?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Juſt fiftie pound, Honey, in good hard Half-crowns.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Trickwell, 'tis your confounded Worſhip puts me to this Charge; but an I catch thee, an I do not charge thee with as many Irons, mayſt thou cozen me again, Knave, mayſt thou cozen me again. Well, Wife, is the Barber come? I'll be trim'd, and then to my Neighbour Gliſtens the Goldſmith to new furniſh my ſelf with Plate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Truely Huſband, ſurely-Heaven is not pleas'd with our Vocation; we wink at the ſins of our Cuſtomers, our Wines are meerly Proteſtant, and I now ſpeak it with grief of heart, we frie Fiſh with ſalt Butter, to the burthen of my Conſcience, calling our Wines by fortie heatheniſh names to diſguiſe truth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Hold your prating; a Pox of your Conſcience, go minde your buſineſs in the Bar, ſcore double, and mend the matter with a vengeance.
sp.stage: [Exit Mrs. Daſh▪ lays the money on the Table.
Enter Trickwell dreſt like a Barber.
sp.p: How now, Friend, what are you?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: A Barber, Sir, the Widow Scowres man, an't like your Worſhip; my name's Timothy Hazard, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Very well, very well; and how does my Godſon, Timothy?

div.stage: [Daſh. ſits down in a Chair, he puts the things about him.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Very well, an't like your Worſhip; he's gone to trim Parſon Cuffett.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: And how long have you been a Barber, Timothy?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: A Year, an't like your Worſhip, come Chriſtmas.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: What, what, and a good Workman, Timothy? And may I truſt my ſelf in thy hands, Timothy?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Oh doubt me not, Sir, I'll ſhave your Worſhip as cleverly, as your Worſhip ſhall confeſs, by that time I've done.—Hah, 'tis Caſh!

div.stage: Whilſt he is waſhing him they talk.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Well, Timothy, and what's the News, Timothy? You Barbers are notable News-mongers, good Commonwealthsmen: You—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Marrie, Sir, I know none but of the Speaking Childe and the Monſter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: How, the Monſters! what Monſters, good Timothy?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Has not your Worſhip heard of the Monſter, the Graveſend-Monſter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: By my Troth not I.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Why, Sir, there came aſhore laſt night four and twentie huge horrible monſterous devouring—

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Bleſs us! what?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Whales, Sir; which no ſooner came aſhore, but they turn'd into fearful Elephants that roar'd, then into Cockatrices that crow'd and frighted all the Judges out of Weſtminſter-hall.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Good Lord!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And in a moment theſe Cockatrices were turn'd into ſo many huge Giants in Scarlet, with Triple Crowns on their heads, and forked Tongues that hiſs ſo loud, the noiſe is heard to the Royal Exchange; which has put the Citizens into ſuch a Conſternation, that 'tis thought the world's at an end.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Good Lord! And what may this portend, Timothy?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Portend, Sir, Poperie, Sir, Poperie; and theſe Monſters are call'd the four and twentie Whores of Babylon.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
Oh monſterous! Four and twentie Whores! the Nation will be over-run with Poperie indeed, Timothy: Bleſs us, what monſterous things are theſe Popiſh Monſters! Well, in grace of God my Wife and I will go ſee theſe four and twentie Whores.
Nay, nay, God bleſs little England; this muſt portend rightdown Poperie, that's certain. Well, and haſt thou no merrie News, Timothy?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, they ſay that there's five and twentie couple of Bears are to dance a Dance in Paris-Garden before the King; and four and twentie couple of French Apes play to 'em upon Flute doux.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh Pox, Timothy, this muſt be a lye, Timothy; and this be not a lye, I am an Aſs efaith: Four and twentie Bears dance to Flutes douxes! Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: 'Tis credible reported, Sir.—Shut your Eyes cloſe, Sir, cloſer yet, Sir, this Ball will make 'em ſmart.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Aye, aye, Timothy, I do wink.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, your head will take cold; [Puts on a fools cap. I'll put on your good Worſhips Night-cap. So, now I'll ſhave you, Sir. This muſt •• ong with me, this Beaver too, and now adieu, worſhipful Mr. Daſhit.

div.stage: Leaves him in the Suds, the Baſon in's hand, and runs away with the money. Exit.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Four and twentie couple of Engliſh Bears dance to the Muſick of French Apes! Ha, ha, ha! in faith, good Timothy, thou makeſt my Worſhip ſmile,—But heark ye, Timothy, doſt know one Trickwell? a villanous Rogue, Timothy, cheated me laſt night of Fiftie pound in Plate; but I'll Plate him, with a Pox, an I catch him. Come, haſte, good Timothy. Art thou free, Timothy? I am one of the Common Council, Timothy, and may do thee good ſhortly. Why Timothy! Timothy! doſt leave me in the Suds? Why Timothy! I ſhall be blinde with winking. [wipes his Eyes.] Timothy! Hah, you—Wife, my money, Wife!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: What's the noiſe here? you are always bawling.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: 'Owns, ye Whore, where's Timothy?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: What Timothy?

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Why the Barber, Jade, the Barber.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: The Barber! I ſaw him go half a quarter of an hour ſince. Why, are you not trim'd?

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Trim'd, a Pox trim ye; where's the money, the money, the money, ye Jade? I am trim'd with a vengeance!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: What's the money gone! the whole Fiftie pound in the bag!

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: I have wink'd fair, in the Devils name.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Pray, Godfather, give me your Bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: A Pox of Bleſſing, I am Curſing, Rogue: where's Timothy, thy Mothers man Timothy?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: My Mother has no ſuch, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: My money! my fiftie pound! A Plague of all Timothies; who was't trim'd me?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I know not, Godfather; onely one met me and borrow'd my Furniture, for a Jeſt, he ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: What kind of Fellow was't? Oh—

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: A little ſlender nimble well-ſpoken fellow, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Oh 'tis Trickwell, that Rogue Trickwell! a black Hair and Eye-brows, and grey Eyes?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes, Godfather.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Aye, aye, 'tis he. Raiſe the ſtreet upon him; I'll hang him if there be Law for money. Oh I ſhall faint! Wife, wife, fetch me the Roſa ſolus.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Good Huſband, take comfort in the Lord, I'll play the Devil but I'll recover it; have a good heart, 'tis but a weeks falſe ſcoring in the Parliament-time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: So, ſome comfort: Wife, whe Wife, I ſay, is there any Muſick in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Yes, Sweet-heart, Mr. Squeeks Noyſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Bid 'em play then: And John come kiſs me now, now, now, and John come kiſs me now. [ſings.] Bid 'em play; laugh thou and be merrie, for I'll go dance, caſt up my Accounts, and hang my ſelf preſently. I will not curſe, but a Pox on Trickwell, he has ſhav'd me, he has trim'd me! I will go hang my ſelf; but firſt let's have a Dance.

div.stage: Exeunt dancing with the bottle in's hand, and ſings, John come kiſs me, &c.

div.head: SCENE the Firſt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: COme, prithee Ample, ſing the Song Wellman made upon the Kiſs I gave him.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: No, prithee don't, my ſtomack turns againſt kiſſing extreamly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, Diana?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: By the faith I have in this Beautie, 'tis the moſt unſavorie Ceremonie, the moſt ſawcie Cuſtom to Ladies; every Fellow now-a-daies with greaſie ſweatie Faces, ſtinking Breath, and naſtie Teeth, muſt take a bodie over the Lips with ſuch familiaritie; nay they think 'tis grateful to us too. Lord, there was an old Judge laid me over the face laſt night, and did ſo ſqueeze his grizly Briſsles through my Lips, I'd as live a kiſt a row of Pins with the points to me; and yet I was forc'd to take it, take it with a Curtſie too: for my part I had as lieve they ſhould belch in my face.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fie, what a Compariſon's there!

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Sutable to the beaſtly Complement; and yet I love kiſſing too, if I may chuſe my man and place.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fie, if any one ſhou'd hear ye!

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Let a thouſand, I'd not be aſham'd; 'tis not thoſe that talk roguiſhly, that are to be ſuſpected: you ſhall have a hypocritical holy Siſter mince that publickly, that ſhe'll receive with open arms privately: For my own part, I conſider Nature without Apparel, without diſguiſing; I give thoughts, words, and truth, a modeſt boldneſs; I love no prohibited things, and I wou'd have nothing prohibited but by Vertue.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But we muſt conſider the world, who thinks ſevere modeſtie a womans Vertue.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Vertue is freedom, handſome, cheerful mirth; I hate a ſevere, froward, ignorant, ill-bred behaviour in a woman; 'tis uncivil, hang't, I'll have none on't. Ample, what think you?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I can onely ſtand up for Kiſſing; I never ventur'd farther, tho I wou'd fain.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Thou art not of my minde; for I'll nere marrie.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Marrie God forbid! what will you do then?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Ene ſtrive againſt the fleſh: Marrie! no, faith, Huſbands are like Lots in a book, one may prick a hundred times and finde all blanks. A Huſband! a Hangman: a careleſs domineering inſolent thing, that grows like Corral, whilſt under water, ſoft and tender; but married, and above the waves, hard, ſtubborn, not to be bow'd nor manag'd: whilſt your humble ſervant, Oh how aſſiduous, troubleſomely officious and buſie; but wed, the worſtbred Tyrant and Sloven in nature. No, no, I'll live my own woman, I—and let the worſt come to the worſt, I had rather be call'd Wanton than a Fool.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh but a vertuous Marriage!

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Vertuous Marriage! there's no more affinitie between Vertue and Marriage, than a man and his Horſe: Wedlock may manage Vertue in the right way, but 'tis oftner looſe and unbridled. I hate reſtraint upon my Vertue, or to owe it to the honour of a Huſband; yet I like thy match well enough, a handſome man, good humour, wittie, and wilde; but my Sir John is ſuch a tool, fit to make nothing but a Cuckold of. See if they be not here.

div.stage: Enter Sir John Emptie and Wellman.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: My ſweet Marinda!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Good morrow, my little Sooterkin; how is't, my prettie Life?—Nay, I call all my Miſtriſſes ſo.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Indeed! How many Miſtriſſes have you had?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Some Nine, or thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Then you have had nine lives, like a Cat.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Mew—you wou'd be kiſt for that.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Yes, if I lik'd the mouth that offer'd it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: By my troth, that muſt not be mine; I do not love to endanger my back with ſtooping ſo low: if you wou'd wear Chipeeners, much might be done.—Nay, let me alone to finde a Rowland for your Oliver.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Your peſtilent wit will never make me aſham'd of my ſhortneſs: the faults I can mend my ſelf, I bluſh at; but thoſe which Nature made, let her bear the ſhame for me, I have nothing to do with it; but you never forget to be wittie on my Beautie, Sir Knight, I ſhall be even with you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nor remember, by my troth, but as I do Religion, for Controverſie ſake onely, no hurt.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: But, Brother, for I'll now call you ſo, ſince my Father this night reſolves to contract you—Shall we not have Fiddles and dance? Sir John I'm ſure will make one, and my Citie Lover the Aldermans ſon, Mr. Shatter, he's a moſt ſpruce Dancer of the firſt bench in the School, I'll promiſe ye.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Fore Gad, and well remember'd, he borrow'd a Diamond-Ring of me laſt night to make a Viſit in to a Ladie; and was't you? The Devil take me, an I had thought that, he ſhou'd nere a had it. Adſbud he's here!

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.p: Good day to my fair Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Good morrow, ſweet Mr. Shatter.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Shatter! Pox on him, is he a Rival now?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: You're fine to day, rich in Jems, Mr. Shatter.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.p: A Toy, Madam, I bought to pleaſe my finger.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: I am more pretious to you than your finger; why not to oblige me? Come, I'm no profeſs'd beggar, you know.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.p: Faith and troth, Madam, as I hope to be ſav'd—Oh Lord, as the ſaying is—I proteſt upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Do not pawn it for ſuch a trifle.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.p: As I'm a Gentleman, as God ſhall ſa' me, I'll give a—

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Is this yours to give?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Madam, that's ſuch a thing now, why ſhou'd your Ladyſhip—you're the ſtrangeſt Joker, I proteſt.—

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Hum! now I remember, I think I have ſeen this on a perſons hand, an humble ſervant of mine, one Sir John Empty.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.p: Pox of her memorie! a ſuch another Madam. Whe, what a Devil's he to her now?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Nay, I'm ſure this is it.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.p: Troth, 'tis, Madam: the poor fellow wanted a little money to treat ſome women laſt night, and ſo he pawn'd it to me. 'Tis a Pawn, good faith, or elſe you ſhou'd have it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Heark ye, thou baſe lying ſon of a cheating Cit, how dares thy impudence hope to proſper? Were it not for the reſpect I bear this noble Companie, I wou'd ſo bang thee!—

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: How now, what's the matter here?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.p: Nothing, Madam, nothing. He was a little uncivil with me laſt night; for which, becauſe I ſhou'd not call him to an account, he deſir'd to make me any ſatisfaction. The Coward trembles at my very preſence; but I have him on the hip, I'll take the forfeit of his Ring.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Heark ye, Sir, what's that you whiſper to her?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir, but to ſatisfie her that the Ring was yours, not pawn'd to me, but lent to grace my finger; and ſo I told her I begg'd your pardon for being a little too familiar with your Reputation.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Yes indeed, he did; and ſaid you wou'd make him any ſatisfaction for a rudeneſs you did him laſt night, but he wou'd take the forfeit of the Ring for't.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: How now, ye baſe Scoundrel!

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.p: Hold, hold, my Miſtriſs does but rally, faith.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Thy Miſtriſs! I diſown thee; thou'rt a childe, I'll give thee to my woman. Come, Siſter, let's make us ready for the Ball anon. Come, you ſhall be friends.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: He ſhall renounce you then, and reſtore my Ring; Adſbud he ſhall.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.p: With all my heart, to do you ſervice, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And here I make an offer of it.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Well, I'll take it, Sir, to make me thine to night. Farewel, Brother, till anon.

div.stage: Exit Mar. Dian. Sir John, & Amp.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: To be huft thus by a Coward, a beaten Coward, what madneſs has poſſeſt thee?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.p: Aye, but how the Devil did I know he was a Coward? cou'd not you have whiſper'd me that?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I'll try to make your peace with Diana. Leave me, I've buſineſs now. [Exit Shat. Enter Friend.] How now, my friend! what news from Love? is the Ladie of ſin kinde? prithee ſay how; in faith I'll not be angrie.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Oh, Wellman! no Age did ere produce ſo damn'd a Creature ſo fair, and yet ſo falſe: had I been vicious, what a deſperate wretched thing I'd been!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Prithee what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Heaven! I have been tempted to thy death.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: What is the Furie mad?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Moſt damnable!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Hearing I'm to be marri'd.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: She rav'd at firſt like winds let looſe to ruine, But fixt on this reſolve, ſhe calm'd again, And liſten'd to my love, my eager love; which when it urg'd her to create me happie, ſhe preſt me to this Murder, as the way, the onely means to gain her heart for ever. Mad with my flame, I cou'd deny her nothing, and then my lawleſs luſt, not I, proteſted, confirm'd it with a thouſand Oaths to kill ye, and bring this Ring to witneſs you were dead; and then her lovely bodie was my hire.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Horrid! nothing's defam'd but by its proper ſelf: Phyſicians abuſe Remedies, Lawyers ſpoil Law, and woman onely is a ſhame to woman. You've vow'd to kill me?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Moſt ſolemnly; for, friend, I muſt enjoy her. Oh that a man of ſenſe ſhou'd fancie pleaſure in one whoſe ſoul's ſo black
and infamous; but 'tis my fate, and I muſt bow before it.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt; I will contrive the means to ſatisfie thee. Come, I give a Ball to night to my Marinda; thou ſhalt be there: and by the way, I'll tell thee what we will do to make a ſeeming Quarrel, that all the world, as well as this Corina, may think I'm kill'd indeed, whilſt I, lodg'd in ſome place obſcure, may give thee time to cool this feavouriſh blood. Shew her this Ring, proteſt me ſurely dead; and when thou'rt ſatiated, we'll laugh at follie. Come, let us go.

div.head: SCENE changes to the ſtreet, a ſhop-door.
div.stage: Enter Mr. Gliſten and Daſhit, with a great ſilver Baſon or Punch-bowl. Enter Trickwell in the habit of a Pedler with a box with Trinkets before him. Jervice.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Well, Neighbour Gliſten, I am beholden to you for this credit till next week, and I am pleaſed in my choice of this piece of Plate; a Punch-bowl is a moſt faſhonable thing, now French Wines are prohibited: I know 'twill pleaſe my Wife. Well, I am fortie pound indebted to you for't, honeſt Mr. Gliſten.

sp.speaker: Gliſt.
sp.p: Your word's ſufficient, Sir, an 'twere for a thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: A Pox of the Rogue that robb'd me! Well, I ſhall catch him; and if I do, he ſhall half rot in Fetters in the Dungeon till he deſpair; then I'll hire a Parſon on purpoſe that ſhall perſwade him he is damn'd; then after ſee him with my own eyes hang'd without ſinging any Pſalm: Lord, Lord, that he ſhou'd have but one neck!

sp.speaker: Gliſt.
sp.p: Oh, Neighbour, you muſt uſe a Conſcience in all things; but do your will. You'll command me no farther?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: No, onely lend me your ſervant to carrie this Bowl home to my Peg; I am to ſtep into Leaden-hall.

sp.speaker: Gliſt.
sp.p: Willingly, Sir: Here, Jervice, carrie home this Plate.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: To my Wives own hands deliver it, good Jervice.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: To her own hand, honeſt Jervice.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: I have deliver'd better things than this to a womans own hand, Sir, before now.

div.stage: Exit Jer. with the Bowl, and Gliſten in.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Monſieur, pleaſe you to buy a very fine delicate Ball, a ſweet Ball, a Camphere-ball.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Prithee away.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: One a Ball to ſhave, one a Ball to ſcowre.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Name 'em not to me, talk not of ſhaving; a Pox of the Rogue, I have been ſhav'd, I have.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I'll ſhave ye ſmoother yet: That Bowl, that delicious Bowl, I muſt be drunk out of; I have a fancie for't, it is too good for cheating Vintners: I ſay it muſt be mine; therefore, my worſhipful Daſhit, look to't: What tho there be rounds in a Ladder, and knots in a Halter? hang the Devil, I'll do't; I muſt draw a Lot for the great Punch-bowl.

div.head: SCENE changes to Mr. Daſhit's houſe.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Daſhit and Jervice with the Bowl.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Nay, Jervice, ſtay and drink, good Jervice; and how does Mrs. Gliſten? I knew her well, ſhe was a very good patient Creature, efaith; ſhe has born, and born, and bore again, good woman, as well as I, with a bad Huſband; yet I can finde no fault in Mr. Gliſten: Here's to him, Jervice, he knew me before I was married; an honeſt man he is, [drinks] and a thriftie, I'll warrant him; and his Wife's a proper woman as any in Cheapſide.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Yes, indeed forſooth, ſo ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: She paints now, and yet ſhe keeps her Huſband's Cuſtomers ſtill. Introth, Jervice, a handſome Wife in a fine carv'd ſeat, is the beſt Ware in a mans ſhop.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Yes, indeed forſooth, ſo 'tis.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: But well, Jervice, remember me to your Maſter and Miſtriſs, and tell 'em I acknowledge the receipt of this, acknowledge the receipt.—This 'tis to have good Education, and to be brought up in a Tavern; and though my Huſband be a Citizen, all London knows I keep as good Companie as any ſhe within the Walls. Good day, honeſt Jervice.

div.stage: Enter Trickwell dreſt like a Prentiſe, with a Jole of Salmon.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Fair hour to you, Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: A prettie Complement! I'll write it down: A beautiful thought to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Your Huſband and my Maſter Mr. Gliſten has ſent you a Jole of freſh Salmon, and they intend to come both to Dinner preſently to ſeaſon your new Bowl, forſooth, which your Huſband intreats you wou'd ſend back by me, that his Arms may be engraven on it, which he forgot before.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſhit.
sp.p: Are you ſent by no Token? Nay, I have a wit.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes forſooth, by the ſame Token he was dry ſhav'd this morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: A ſad Token, but true: here, pray commend me to your Maſter and Miſtriſs, and tell 'em I expect 'em impatiently.
sp.stage: Gives him the Bowl, takes the Salmon. Exit Trick.
sp.p: Impatient was well again! Sam! why Sam, I ſay!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Anon, anon, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Come quickly, ſpread the Table, lay Napkins, and do ye hear? perfume the Room a little; it does ſo ſmell of this prophane Tobacco! I could never endure this ungodly Tobacco, ſince our Doctor told me 'twas a bane to Propagation.—So ſpread handſomly: Lord, theſe Boys do things ſo arſie-verſie! You ſhew your breeding. Well, I am a Gentlewoman by my Siſters ſide, I can tell you: ſo—methodically. Hum! I wonder where I got that word! Oh 'twas Sir John Empty bid me kiſs him methodically; 'tis a ſweet man!

sp.speaker: Mr. Daſh.
sp.p: Well, Tony Daſhit, be not diſcourag'd, be not diſheartned, thou wilt recover all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Oh are you come, Huſband? where are they?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: How now! how now! how now! what, a Feaſt towards! and in my private Parlour! Who treats, who treats, Peg?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Prithee leave fooling; are they come?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Come! who come?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Lord, How ſtrange you make it!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Strange! what's ſtrange? is the woman mad!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Aye ſtrange: You know of none that ſent me a Jole of Salmon, you—and ſaid they wou'd come dine with me!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Hah, freſh Salmon! peace, not I; peace, the Meſſenger has miſtaken the houſe: let's eat it up quickly, before it be inquir'd for. Come, come, Vineger quickly, Sam.—Some good luck yet, efaith; I never taſted Salmon that reliſht better in my life. Well, 'tis a rare thing to feed at other mens coſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Other mens coſt! prithee did not you ſend this Salmon?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: No, I ſay, no.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: By Mr. Gliſten's man?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I ſay no.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Who ſent word that he and his Wife wou'd come to dinner with me?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: No, no.

div.stage: He eats like mad all this while. He lays down, his knife and ſtarts.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: And hancel my new Bowl.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Hah, Bowl!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: And withal, commanded me to ſend the Bowl back.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Hah, back!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: That your Arms might be put on't.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: By the ſame token that you were dry ſhaven this morning.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: And thereupon I ſent back the Bowl: nay, and I bear not a brain—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: And is the Bowl gone? is it deliver'd departed? defunct? hah!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Delivered? yes ſure, 'tis delivered.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I will never more ſay my Prayers; and is the Bowl gone?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Gone: God is my witneſs I deliver'd it with no more deſigne to be cozen'd on't, than the childe unborn.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Look to my houſe, I am haunted with Evil Spirits: hear me, thou Plague to man, thou Wife thou, if I have not my Bowl again, I will go to the Devil; I'll to a Conjurer: look to my houſe, I'll raiſe all the Wiſe men in London.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Bleſs me, what fearful words are theſe! I truſt in God he is but drunk ſure.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I muſt have my Salmon, I cannot afford the old Rogue ſo good a bit; I muſt have it to ſeaſon my Punch. Now for a Maſter-piece: Fair Miſtriſs—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Oh have I caught ye! Sam, ſhut up the doors, Sam.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Peace, good Miſtriſs, I'll tell you all: A Jeſt, a meer Jeſt; your Huſband did it onely to fright ye: the Bowl's at my Maſters, and thither your Huſband's gone, and has ſent me in all haſte, leſt you ſhou'd be over-frighted, to invite you to come to dinner to him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Praiſe Heaven 'tis no worſe!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And bad me deſire you to ſend the Salmon before, and your ſelf to follow: My Miſtriſs will be very glad to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: I pray take it. Well, I was never ſo out of my wits in my life: Pray thank your Miſtriſs. [Exit Trick. with the Salmon.] How my heart beats ſtill, beſhrew him! Sam, my Hood, Sam, and Gloves, and Scarf, quickly.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: How now, whither are you janting, hah?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Come, play the fool no longer, will you go?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Whither, in the name of Madneſs, whither?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Whither! why to Mr. Gliſten's to eat the Salmon. How ſtrange you make it!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Your meaning, Jade, your meaning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Lord bleſs me, did not you ſend for me and for the Salmon, by the ſelf-ſame fellow that came for the Bowl?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: 'Tis well, 'tis wonderous well! and are you in your right wits, Jade, are you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: An you make an Aſs of me, I'll make an Ox of you, I tell ye that.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Nay, Jade, be patient; for look ye, I may be mad, or drunk, or ſo; tho you can bear more than I, I do well: I will not curſe; but Heaven knows my minde. Come, let's go hear ſome Muſick. I will never pray again, that's certain: Let's go hear ſome doleful Muſick. Nay; if Heaven forget to proſper Knaves, the Citie's like to thrive: I'll go hang my ſelf out of the way.

div.head: SCENE the Firſt.
