div.stage: Enter Sir Lyonell, Mr. Wellman, Friendly, Sir John Emptie, Mr. Shatter, Marinda, Diana, Petronella, and other women and men; with Muſick.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: MOre Lights there, Boy, more Wine and Lights.—Come, come, ſon Wellman, for ſo I muſt call you now; introth you are not merrie, Sir, not heartily merrie: Come, we'll have tother Dance, efact we will, Mr. Wellman. Diana, whe Girl, I ſay! Adſme you're all out of ſorts; I thought thy Tongue and heels cou'd never have been idle: Come, come, hands, hands, for ſhame.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Come, Mrs. Diana, I'm your man at this ſport; I never ſtand out at theſe buſineſſes: Your hand, fair Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You lie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Do I, Sir? I vow to God, I aſk your pardon, Sir; I durſt to have ſworn I'd been in the right.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: What, quarrelling about the Spoil before the Victorie!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, as for that matter, I'm a man of Reaſon, and Frank Friendly's an honeſt fellow, and my friend.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You lie again, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Well, well, Sir, you are diſpos'd to be merrie, or ſo, but there be more Ladies—Whe, what the Devil ails he, tro?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.p: Pox on't, how rarely he huffs now! Well, it's a moſt admirable thing this ſame Courage, if a man had but the knack on't!

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Come, Zouks, you're tardie, villanous: Young Men and Maids, to't, to't, I ſay, and do not idle time. Come, Minſtrels, play away, efaith my dancing-days are not done yet.

div.stage: Muſick plays, they dance, at the end of which, Well. ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Friendly, you're out.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Death, you lie!

div.stage: Strikes him, he draws, they paſs, the Company puts in all but Shat. & Sir John, who run in corners.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: The Quarrel, Gentlemen, the Quarrel! efaith, here's fine doings!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you have the advantage of the place.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I do believe I have; and you're not ſafe here: I'll meet you, Sir, anon.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Do ſo. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For Heavens ſake, Sir, come back—what wou'd you do? if there be ought that you take ill from Well man, declare it here, and let us end the Quarrel. I know 'tis ſome miſtake; I know he loves you: let not a trifle ſet ſuch friends at odds. Speak to him, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Why how now, Sir, is this the proof you give me of your Love! Oh you have ſhew'd your ſelf a gallant Spark! I thought it Jealouſie, and took it kindly your rudeneſs to our Knight here; but to a friend, at leaſt the man you call ſo, gives me ſome cauſe to fear you're angrie at his Contract with my Siſter. Be friends, or I'll believe ſo.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Do ſo, I care not.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Hah! do you not love me? Do not make me ſerious, I ſhall be out of humour if you do; and Heaven knows what a ſtrange thing I may prove then; I never tri'd it yet.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I care not; pray unhand me.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: I will, in ſpight of all that wou'd detain thee. I never found my ſelf thus much concern'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: What ſudden flaw is this?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: By Heaven, I know not, Sir, unleſs ſome hidden flame for thee—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It cannot be, I never ſaw a glance, a look, or ſmile, cou'd be ſuſpected Love: 'tis ſome old Grudge. Dear, do not follow him, my heart preſages ſomething that is fatal. [weeps.] Good Sir perſwade him. To Sir Lyon.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Away, ye fool, perſwade him not to fight! away, a Coward! hang't, he were not worth thy love then.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Honour, my Deer, obliges me to go. Wou'dſt have the man that has thy heart in keeping, be pointed out for Cowardize? Away, thou needſt not fear, we ſhall at moſt onely exchange a Wound. Thy ſacred Image guards my heart entire, and keeps it ſafe from danger. Go to the Banquet, entertain the Ladies, and be merrie.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: By Cocks bones ſhall ſhe, and be very merrie, to think ſhe's like to have ſo briſk a Spark to her Bed-fellow. Go thy ways, William, and God's bleſſing go with thee, Boy: if thou wants a ſecond, I can puſh yet, I'm not ſo old efaith.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I humbly thank ye, Sir; we ſhall think better on't perhaps before we fight.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Or ſhall Sir John go? he's a man of mettle, I aſſure you, Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What the Devil do ye mean! I have mind to take this opportunitie to be with thee, thou little wanton—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Fear not, Sir, I'll excuſe ye.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You little amiable miſchievous Ape you, what a ſeurvie malicious Jeſt did you break upon me, to make the Proverb good, You had rather loſe your Friend than your Jeſt?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: A Jeſt! it was a parlous true one then: I ſaid you were all Mettle; A brazen face, a leaden brain, and a copper noſe and beard.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Wit, Lightning, and Quick-ſilver, thou little more than Dwarf, and ſomething leſs than woman.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: A Waſp, a Waſp! Your Wit ſtings, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Thou'rt plaguie ſharp; pray God thou be'ſt not too far gone in Love; if thou ſhou'dſt, I muſt be forc'd in honour to marrie thee, tho introth't wou'd be hardly brought about.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p:
No matter, Sir; things got by ſtrugling, bring the greater pleaſure, when dull Conſent but palls the Appetite. Then thou'rt a fool too, the moſt admirable neceſſary for a Huſband in
the whole Creation, and the beſt Block to carve a Cuckold in.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Whe, what a tart Monkey's this! By my troth if thou hadſt not ſo much wit, I cou'd finde in my heart to take thee for better for worſe; for I finde thou cou'dſt bear me with all my faults.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Bear with thee! I wonder how thy Mother bore thee nine whole months about her, when I'll be ſworn I can ſcarce endure thee in my ſight an hour.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Alas for you, ſweet Soul, good lack! A pox of your Wit: By the Lord Harry, you are the proudeſt, ſcoffing, ſcurvie, idle, fantaſtical, whimſical—Ads nigs, becauſe you have read St. George for England, Amades de Gall, and the Legend of Lyes, you are licens'd, forſooth, to abuſe all the world: Egad, Sir Lyonell, your Father ſhall know't.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: He muſt not tho—Nay, do not go in Rancor, good dear Knight; for I muſt confeſs a ſecret to you; which if you knew my heart, you wou'd believe there were nothing ſo cruel there as you imagine. I ſpeak very kinde things of you between my Maid and I anight as I am going to bed, and next my Prayers too, Heaven forgive me! I ſpoke things of you that I wou'd not wiſh you ſhou'd know.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nay, look ye, for my part, if I have not moſt religiouſly vow'd my heart yours, been drunk twice a day to your health, ſwallow'd Fire and inches of your Cuff-ſtrings, eat Candles, pledg'd your health in Chamber-lie, run Pins into my Arms, and done all manner of gallant and heroick actions, I'm the verieſt ſon of a Whore breathing; and yet to tell me after all this, I have a brazen face, a leaden brain, and a copper noſe, [weeps.] 'tis moſt intolerable, inſupportable, and prodigious, I'll be ſworn.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: And de ye love me ſo indeed?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Love you! 'Sbud, whoſoever ſays I do not, and honour you too, Egad; nay, and if you wou'd, wou'd marrie you, is a ſon of a Whore, and a Scoundrel, by the Lord.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: And let me tell you in return, that—Heaven forgive me! And my Siſter knows I have took drink and ſlept upon't, that if ever I marrie, it ſhall be you; and I will marrie, and yet I hope I do not ſay it ſhall be you neither. Come, let's to the Banquet.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
Oh, dear Creature, I do not ſay you do: Lord, how was I miſtaken in thy heart! But will you hereafter caſt a kinde
look at me, to put me in countenance before Companie? That I wou'd be at now.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Much may be done. Come, let's to the Banquet.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And will you, my prettie little Darling of mine eyes, marrie me? As I hope to breath, my Purſe, Bodie, Soul and all, ſhall be thine.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Moſt affectionately ſpoken! Well, get my Fathers conſent, and as for mine—the Devil take me if ever thou gets it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A Kiſs, and 'tis a Match. Thus Hymen ſhou'd begin; A falling out, ſometimes proves falling in.

div.stage: Enter Wellman and Friendly, as in the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Well, my dear friend, tell me with open heart, hath not my Reaſoning reclaim'd thy Folly, preſerv'd thy falling Vertue, and ſecur'd it?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: There is no Vertue in Blood, no Reaſoning in Deſire: But ſhall I not in this fond act of Love, do that which will to thee render my name abhorr'd, and make thee hate me?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: By Heaven, no.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And ſhall I then? may I enjoy Corina?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt, by all our Friendſhips. Here, take this Ring, ſhew it to that fair Devil, it will confirm me dead; which rumour, with my abſence, will make good—Poſſeſs thy Love, grow wearie in her Arms, then be thy ſelf again.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But if Report grows ſtrong, and I am ſeiz'd, where ſhall I finde thee?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: At Gliſtens my Goldſmith in Cheapſide, to whom I'll tell our buſineſs and deſigne.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thither I'll come and tell thee how I thrive. Till when, farewel.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: When woman's in 〈◊〉 heart, the ſoul's all hell. Now Repentance, the after-clap of • ools, light on thee; I have an Art left that may reclaim thee yet. I'll make thee fall into the vileſt dangers, even worſe than womans Luſt. No Goldſmith will I ſee, or tell my ſtorie to, but in ſome ſit diſguiſe I'll hide my ſelf impoſſible to be diſcover'd, and leave thee to two friends, a Whore and Law, that will be plague ſufficient for one man; but is this friendſhip in me? [pawſes.] No matter:
No man is purely vertuous, no Vertue purely kind;
The end being good, the way is well deſign'd.

div.head: SCENE changes to Corina's houſe.
div.stage: Enter Corina in anger, followed by Trickwell with Plate, and Mrs. Dunwell.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh, impudence, am I then fallen ſo low to be ſollicited by Pimps and Panders! Hell take the trade, if this be the effects on't.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Madam, whatever you may think of me, my Preſent has the ſhew of Qualitie; here's Plate, a Preſent that a Lord might make ye; and I was once a Gentleman, tho I am fallen ſo low by faithleſs Vice, yet tho undone, poor and depriv'd of all, I have a heart and will, that ſtill remains, and fain wou'd venture on when Beautie calls. And if I have a ſtock, which Heaven and my own induſtrie has lent, I muſt employ it ſtill to that dear uſe. Take firſt this little Tribute of my conquer'd heart; I may in time increaſe it: were it Crowns, here they ſhou'd all be offer'd.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And thus I'd ſpurn away: Baſe ſervile Villain, who liveſt by Noiſe and Riot, ſpunging upon the drops that fall from Gentlemen, canſt thou believe that after Wellman's love, I cou'd receive a Raſkal to my Arms?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: If I were there, you'd finde but little difference; and poſſibly the next they entertain may fail to pay this price I offer ye. This Raſkal and that beautious haughtie thing, bating the Sex, differ but very little. I live by Brauls, by rapine, and by Spoils, in Fears, Vexations, Dangers, ſo do you; I eat when I can get a fool to treat me, and you can do no more: Pox of your pride, methinks we two might underſtand each other; you've no Gallant to take your Quarrels up; you raign'd when time was, and I'll do ſo now, for you have known my love, ſhall finde my power, tho yet I nere durſt tell you ſo.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Nor ſhall not yet; for tho that Lover's gone, who but to look on wou'd have made thee tremble, I've Beautie ſtill that may command another Beautie whoſe very glance ſhou'd make thee bow: Gods! and has it loſt its awe?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: It has, and I'm reſolv'd upon a Conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
Death, Sirra! ſtand off, and view my fatal hand, it carries death to the bold Raviſher, that dares approach unreverendly. A Whore! what tho to her that bears it 'tis a ſhame, an infamie that cannot be ſupported? to all the world beſides it bears a mightie ſound, petition'd, ſu'd to, worſhipp'd as a God, preſented,
flatter'd, follow'd, ſacrific'd to, Monarch of Monarchs, Tyrant of the world, what does that charming word not ſignifie! And dareſt thou raiſe thy hated eyes ſo high to gaze on ſuch a Conſtellation! No, be gone, with all thy baſe-got worthleſs Triſles, quickly pack up, and hence, or I will kill thee.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: So, Sir, you had better have lookt no higher than Mrs. Mary Dunwell, who can down with you when money's low; but when once a little in Pocket, you are for high feeding, forſooth. Go get you gone, I may chance take pitie on you when her paſſion's over, and do you ſome ſervice.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No, by Heaven, I'll try my chance this very minute, throw my laſt Caſt, for the great Stake is ſet, and will enjoy her now.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Hah! here's ſomebodie I hope will interrupt you.
What wou'd you, Sir? wou'd you have ought with me? A proper handſome fellow, but ill dreſt.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Madam, I am a Gentleman grown poor, decay'd by fortune, and wou'd gladly ſerve: I can obey, cou'd you direct me where.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: This fellow wou'd ſerve my turn moſt admirably! but if I cou'd—you wou'd grow proud with feeding well and clean Linnen.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I am not bred ſo ill, but I can tell how to be grateful to you.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Introth he apprehends moſt diſcreetly—but you're too big to wear a Liverie.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Not at all; 'tis the faſhion now for Ladies to keep tall men in Liveries: your Page is out of faſhion, and your ſtripling Footman.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: [within] Help! help! undone! Oh help!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Hah, what noiſe is that!

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Heavens! the Rogue ſure was raviſhing her.

div.stage: Enter Wellman dragging in Trickwell, Corina follows diſordered.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Damn'd ſawcie Villain, what was thy pretence?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What's that to thee, bold interrupting Slave, ſent by the Devil to hinder my delight?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Dog—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Hold, do not kill the Raſkal; 'tis enough you've ſav'd me from his miſchiefs: pray let him go.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: 'Tis pitie, but I will obey. Take that, and that, that, ye Mungrel Cur; Dogs ſhou'd be us'd ſo. [Kicks him out.] Death! what a very wretched thing's a Whore, that every Raſkal dares approach with Love!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Who are ye, pray, to whom I'm ſo oblig'd?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: One that wou'd gladly ſerve in any qualitie.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I'll do thee good; take that. [Gives him money.] I will prefer thee to ſome man of Qualitie: Mean time make this your home.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I wonder whether Friendly has been here!

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Madam, one knocks; ſhall any have admittance?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Onely falſe Wellman's Friend. You may retire, and wait my farther pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I'll over-hear ye too.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Now, my dear Miſtriſs, Soul of my deſires, I come with all the Spoils of conquering Love, to lay 'em at thy feet. My Stop is dead, the Stop of all my raviſhing Happineſs; and here's the witneſs of my Victorie.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Dead! Wellman dead! Oh thou inhumane friend, that boreſt that title onely to betray him! Dead! and by thee! Heaven, can you let him live! Support me, or I fall to earth with this ſad killing news.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Heavens, Madam, what d'ye mean? or ſhall I vow to you he is not dead?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Hah! not dead!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What wou'd you have me do? When I confirm him dead, you grow inrag'd; and when I ſay he lives, you kill with frowns.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Traytor, and haſt thou then deceiv'd my hopes? and is not Wellman dead? Hell, what is man! how didſt thou ſwear, how didſt thou proſtrate lie, and beg'd to give me any proof of thy falſe Paſſion? I aſk'd thee this; and is it thus you give it! Oh for a quick revenging Power to kill thee!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Calm that dear angrie face, and tell my Love which way it beſt ſhall pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
Is't in thy choice, perjur'd, forſworn, and falſe, to tell me either? Damn thy double Tongue, and all this Beautie that
miſ-led thy truth, if thou hadſt ever any in thy ſoul.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Then ſince it is my deſtinie to offend, which way ſoere I take I'll follow truth, and tell you, Madam, all your ſtrict Commands I did obey, and Wellman is no more.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No more! why what hadſt thou to do with my Commands? Oh thou haſt kill'd all that my ſoul cou'd love! Tho I commanded, yet he was thy friend, and that in generoſitie ſhou'd have ſav'd him. Go from my eyes, far from my thoughts remain.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Is this then the reward of all my Love? What have I done, but been obedient? Had I priz'd my Friendſhip above that Love, wou'd you have took it well? Yes, I will be gone, and to the judging world
Prove who's the greater Criminal you or I:
I kill'd a Friend, you make a Lover die.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I muſt not let him go, till I'm reveng'd. Stay, I relent; Oh ſtay, and give my heart a little time to take leave of its old acquaintance, ere it'go to make a new and unknown choice agen. Alas, I lov'd this Wellman, lov'd him dearly, more than my life.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why did you kill him then?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Why, in my own defence; he gave the firſt, I fear the mortal wound.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Then think it juſt, and think of him no more, but of the dear reward you are to give for all my ſervice. Come, will you not?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I will; but you'll receive it decently, and not with hands diſtain'd i'th'blood of him that lately was ſo dear to me?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Still on that ſubject? do not put me off; I've left the buſineſs of my life undone, and had not power to go about my Pardon, ſo haſtie for the dear reward I was; and is it thus you treat me?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You'll finde me all you wiſh, give me an hours time to compoſe my ſelf; and all this upon my brow is but a modeſt decencie; one hour of joy will chaſe it all away.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Do not you dally with me?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No by Heaven, when you return I'll give ye your reward, and what you moſt deſerve—a Halter 'tis, [Aſide.] falſe and perfidious wretch.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Here, keep this Ring, and think each minutes abſence is a long year in love. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Farewel, vain credulous treacherous fool, farewel. Miſchief inſpire me now with all your Arts; methinks the ſight of this inſtructs my Soul in a moſt noble piece of Villanie: I will to fair Marinda with this Ring, and frame a ſtorie of ſo cunning miſchief, ſhall ſtab her through the ear into the heart. By Heaven, 'tis greatly brave, and I'll begin it: Then when this falſe believer does return, I'll be prepar'd for him—What, Hoe, who waits?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Now what a Devil is this woman grown!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: My Hoods and Fan, and call a Coach immediately: [Exit Dun.] and you, Sir, I muſt beg to wait on me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Where ever you command.—This was happie!

div.head: SCENE changes to Sir Lyonell's houſe.
div.stage: Enter Sir Lyonell, Marinda, Diana and Maid, and Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, good Sir, be not angrie that I ſent; I was afraid ſome harm wou'd come of it, and ſo I fear there is.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: And did no one hear of him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: None; pray Heaven he be well; my heart miſgives me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Well, if he be loſt, there's a brave fellow gone, and in a time the King had need of Souldiers; there's idle Huſbands enough for you, Baggages.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: I have a little kind of a ſcurvie pain too, which I do not uſe to feel about my heart, for Friendly—but none ſhall ſee it in my troubled looks: not that I care who knew the loving ſecret, but I'll not be laught at.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Leave your whimpering, do: Wou'd thou hadſt a heart like thy Siſter here. When wou'd ſhe cry for a man thus?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, when I have as much need of a man as ſhe, that is, when I want one, I cannot diſſemble.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir, ſhe has need enough, and thanks to fortune ſhe's provided for, with your good liking, noble Sir Lyonell.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Come, Sir, let's have one Marriage well over, before we think of another. Wou'd we cou'd hear of theſe Sparks too; 'tis almoſt midnight: they might have ſtaid till day-light, and have kill'd one another like Chriſtians decently, not by dark, as Cats and Dogs worrie each other. I know not what to think on't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here's a Ladie in a Coach below deſires to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: A Ladie at this hour! ſhe ſhall be welcome; old as I am, I'll not deny a Ladie.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: I hope your buſineſs is with me, fair Ladie.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: 'Twou'd be but ill diſpatch'd then.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I know not, Sir; firſt let me crave your name, or are you Father to the fair Marinda?

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: I am, fair Miſtriſs, for want of a better. By the Maſs ſhe's very handſome! [aſide.] This is the Maid you name.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: My time's but ſhort, and what I have to ſay I muſt diſpatch. Madam, you had a Lover once, Young Wellman!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Had! (good Heavens!) I hope and have.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No, Friendly has baſely kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh wretched loſt Marinda!

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Look to my Daughter!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Madam, look up; this great concern he merits not: 'twas pitie brought me here to undeceive ye; his Vows and Soul were mine, intirely mine.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why didſt thou call me back to life again, or ſay in pitie that you undeceiv'd me? If you knew Wellman falſe, why did you ſtay me? You ſhou'd have let me di'd, 't had been more charitable; but if, as you affirm, he lov'd you beſt, which I believe from that fair form of yours, whilſt I remain I needs muſt love you too.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: This muſt be malice ſure!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Madam, do ye know this Ring? he gave it me, and told me ſuch things of your tireſome Paſſion, as gave us cauſe of laughter all the evening.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I cannot blame him that he lov'd me not, when ſo much Beautie as appears in you, gave him permiſſion to adore it: but methinks 'twas ungentile to make a ſport of me; he ſhou'd have pitied follies he created: he lov'd me firſt; alas, I ſought him not. [weeps.] Help me, Diana, for I feeble grow! To morrow ſhou'd have been my Wedding-day, now I invite you to my Funeral; bring Flowers and ſtrow the way to my cold Grave, and lay me down in peace.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Lead her in, and be careful of her; but, Madam—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I cannot hold, I muſt reveal my ſelf; [going ſtops] Yet ſtay, Heavens, ſhall I ſuffer her to die▪ ſo good, ſo gentle, and ſo ſweet a Miſtriſs? Were there but three ſuch women in the world, two might be ſav'd.—Yes, I'll have patience yet to ſee the utmoſt that this Devil aims at.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Confeſt it, ſaid ye, Madam? and to you? on what Acquaintance, pray?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: He was in love with me; and ſeeing no hope of gaining me whilſt Wellman was alive, he pick'd a Quarrel with him, and diſpatch'd him, and vaunted of the Villanie to me. Pleaſe you to go where I'll direct you, Sir, he ſhall confeſs the Murder.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Madam, I'll go; and you, Sir John muſt bear me companie.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Madam, your hand. Roger, go you to Mr. Conſtable, bid him be readie if I have occaſion, and careful who paſſes the ſtreets to night.

div.head: SCENE the Street.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Sayſt thou, Sam, at one Mrs. Dunwell's houſe? whe, ſhe's a Bawd.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, or my intelligence is falſe. There lies a Ladie, Sir, with whom he's deſperately in love; and having no purchaſemoney, 'tis thought, hires the Bawd at the price of's own bodie, to get the young Ladie, Sir: They call her Corina.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Lord, Lord, what will this wicked world come to! And there thou ſayeſt I may be ſure to finde this villanous Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: He never lies from thence all day, Sir, as I am inform'd; 'tis now about his hour of departure, and this way he muſt come.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
Get ye home, Sam; I'll ene take Mr. Conſtable and a Watchman or two, and fall to ſearching. Get ye home, Sam, thou ſhalt have a new Sute for this, honeſt Sam.
[Exit Sam. Well, if I catch the Rogue, he ſhall be hang'd in louſie linnen: I'll hire a Prieſt to make a Papiſt of him before Execution; and when he's dead, I'll piſs on's Grave.—
sp.stage: Enter Trickwell in a C • oke.
sp.p: But ſtay, who comes here? this may be he.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Damn this Corina, this proud ſcornful Beautie, whom I muſt humble and enjoy. I know I am a Rogue not worthie of her love, a Raſkal that have no one Good about me, but that I love: And this damn'd Bawd, to keep me to her ſelf, diſgraces me to Corina.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Aye, aye, this muſt be he—Ware ſhaving, Sir: What ho, the Watch! the Watch! Takes hold of Trickwell's Cloak.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Death! 'tis Daſhit's voice! [Gets from him, and runs out, leaving his Cloak behinde with Daſhit.
Thieves! Thieves! ſtop Thieves!

div.stage: Enter the Watch after, met by Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Who goes there? come before the Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Death, you are a prettie fellow of a Conſtable, to repreſent the King's Perſon indeed! here's a Watch for the Devil! honeſt men are robb'd under your Noſes. A Raſkal in the habit of a Vintner ſet upon me, cri'd ſtand and deliver, in the Kings Highway; he wou'd have had my Purſe, but that my heels ſav'd it: Yet he got my Cloak of rich Camlet, I'll be ſworn, new and fair this morning. If you light on him, ſeize him, and keep him in the Stocks till the Cloak will hang him.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Doubt not our diligence, Maſter, theſe dangerous times.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Something to drink, Maſter, we that take pains for the good of the Nation.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Honeſt men, watch and ſleep not. Good night.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Well, Maſter, we muſt watch better indeed. Is't not ſtrange that Knaves, Rogues, and Thieves, ſhou'd be abroad, and yet we of the Watch, Scrivenors, Exchange-men, and Taylors, never ſtir a foot!

div.stage: Enter Daſhit running with the Cloak.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: An honeſt man and a Citizen.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: The Knave's drunk, and ſpeaks Riddles.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Come afore the Conſtable; what art thou?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: A Vintner.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Bring him neer: Hah, what's here, the Cloak?

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Vintner! is't you? Hold, a rich Camlet-Cloak; 'tis the ſame.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Oh thou Varlet, does not thou know the Wicked cannot ſcape the eyes of the Conſtable?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: What means all this? as I'm an honeſt man and a Citizen, I took the Cloak—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: As you're a Knave, you took the Cloak; we are your witneſſes for that.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: But, Neighbours, hear me, hear who I am.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: A Thief you are, we know.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: My name is Daſhit.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I, I, we'll daſh ye: in with him to the Stocks there, and lock him faſt till morning, that Juſtice Lackbrain may examine him.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Whe, but heark ye—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Mr. Conſtable—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: In, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Am I not ſtark mad yet, not quite an Aſs?

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: You may be in good time, in grace a God, Sir. Well, what wou'd this Citie do, if 'twere not for-ſuch neceſſarie Tyrants as our ſelves to ride the free-born Jades, and humble 'em?

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p: Prithee hold thy prating, minde our-duties, and let's go ſleep in the fear of the Lord.

div.stage: [Ex. all but Daſh. in the Stocks.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Who's there? So ho! ſo ho! [to him Trick. like a Bell-man. I ſhall be mad, loſe my wits, and then be hang'd. Who goes there I ſay? thou mayſt approach without fear, I'm faſt by the heels.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.l: 'Tis Daſhit!
Maids in your Night-rails,
Look to your light Tails,
Keep cloſe your Locks,
And down your Smocks;
Keep a broad Eye,
And a cloſe Thigh.
sp.p: Good morrow, my Maſters all, good morrow.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: A Pox of Eyes and Thighs! Whe, Bell-man.

div.stage: [Trick. comes to him, holds his Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: [Through the Nose.] Good lack, good lack, Mr. Daſhit! whe, what does your Worſhip in the Stocks? pray come out, Sir.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Out, Sir! whe, I tell thee I am lockt.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Lockt! Oh Men, Oh Manners! Oh Times, Oh Night! that canſt not diſcern gravitie and wiſdom, in one of the Common-Council too! Whe, what's your Worſhip in for?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: For? a Plague on't, ſuſpition of Felonie.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Nay, an't be ſuch a trifle, Lord, I cou'd weep to ſee your good Worſhip in this taking: Your Worſhip has been a good friend to me; and tho you have forgot me, I have found your Worſhip's doors open, and I have knockt, and God knows what I have ſav'd; and do I live to ſee your Worſhip ſtockt?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Hah! alas, honeſt man, thou knows me then: Prithee call the Watch, and let the Conſtable know who I am, prithee do; and here, I have ſome money about me.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: 'Tis more than I deſerve, Sir; let me alone for your deliverie.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Do ſo, honeſt Bell-man, and then let me alone with that Knave Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Maids in your Night-rails, &c.
sp.stage: Going out, enter Conſtable and Watch.
sp.p: Mr. Conſtable, who's in the Stocks?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: One Daſhit, for a Robberie. Daſhit he calls himſelf: doſt know him?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Know him!—Well, Mr. Conſtable, what good have you done the Citie! Know him! a moſt notorious Thief; his houſe has been ſuſpected for a Bawdie-houſe many a year; a harbourer of Cut-purſes and Night-walkers; he has been a long time in the black blook, and is he taken now?

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: How? Burladie, Neighbour, we'll not truſt the Stocks with him; we'll to Newgate with him to rights.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Well mov'd, Simon. Come, Sir, come, Sir, out with him.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh, does your Raſkalſhips know me now? I thought you wou'd know me in the end.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Yes, the end of your worſhip we know.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Aye, here's an honeſt fellow can inform ye.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Yes, we thank him, he has inform'd us you are a Pimp and a Thief. Binde him faſt, and to Newgate with him.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: To Newgate! why Bell-man, Rogue, Raſkal? To Newgate, amongſt the prophane Jeſuits too? oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: So, thou art like to thrive in thy Knaverie: Roguerie proſpers with thee. To morrow is the Seſſions at the Old-baily; I'll make him ſhrink with fear, ere I have done. Cou'd I but be reveng'd on this Corina,
I ſhou'd be proſperous indeed;
Some little Devil help me at a pinch at need.

div.head: SCENE the Firſt. Corina's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Sir Lyonel, Sir John, Corina and Wellman, disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: THis is my Lodging, Gentlemen; where, if you'l pleaſe to wait a little, you ſhall both ſee and hear the truth of what I've told you.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: But, Madam, Did he tell you he had kill'd his Friend? tell you himſelf, 'tis ſtrange!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Sir, If you find I wrong him, let me dye. He came all breathleſs, panting to my Chamber, his Sword all bloody, pray'd me to conceal him, for he had murder'd Wellman.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Under favour, Madam, what quarrel had they, ſaid he, 'tis a moſt rare Creature, I'm half in Love already.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Innocently was the unhappy cauſe; they lov'd me, both were Rivals in my Favour, nor knew I which my heart inclin'd to moſt; Wellman had Wit, Youth, Gaity and good Humour, lovely, well made, fit to engage a heart; and Friendly too was handſom, very diſcreet, very Amorous, ſoft in his Language, modeſt in his Actions; and tho' their Charms were different, yet 'twas hard to ſay who was the greater Conquerour; ſo I by favouring both, made either jealous.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: S'bud, wou'd I had ſhar'd of that without the danger?

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: But Wellman was to have married my Daughter Marinda; to morrow was the day.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: To pleaſe his Father, Sir, he made you think ſo, he has oft with ſighs to me confeſs'd he could not love Marinda, I hope ſhe will believe, and dye in rage, and then I ſhou'd lye contented in my Grave.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: I pity thee, in troth now; but he was ſuch a Villain, that but for his Fathers ſake I'd let him dye unreveng'd—but Sir Jeffery Wellman's my Friend, and therefore I'l be diſpos'd by you.

sp.speaker: Dunw.
sp.p: Madam, here's the Villainous man come—as gay as a young Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Pray Sir retire with theſe Gentlemen into my Cloſet, and you ſhall hear he will confeſs the murder, and having witneſs, you may apprehend him, and do you the while prepare the Watch, and let 'em wait below.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: With what a Fury is a Whore inrag'd?

div.stage: [Puts Sir Lyonel and Sir John into the Cloſet, and Wellman and Dunwell go out.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: So now my Revenge grows high, cou'd I but hang this Friendly, which I wou'd becauſe 'twas Wellman's Friend, and make Marinda mad,
Oh! with what Joy I'd follow—for 'tis I
Muſt end the laſt Act of the Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Now, my Corina, now, my Heavenly Fair,
I come to take that Joy which from thy Eyes
I find thou wilt allow my panting heart—
And here upon my knees receive my Vow;
If ever I prove falſe to ſo much Beauty
May I be ever ſcorn'd by Men and Heaven!
Oh! the exceſſive Joy that fills my Soul
With thought of my approaching happineſs.
Come, lets draw nearer to our bliſs, thy Chamber—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: But ſtay—

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh! do not kill me with that fatal ſtay.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You have not told me yet how you kill'd Wellman.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh! name him not, ſome fit of Love or Rage will ſeize thy Soul at naming him, and ruin me. My dear Corina, Miſtris of my Life, name him no more.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Now, on thy Life, by all I hold moſt dear, now Wellman is no more, the repetition will be wondrous grateful. Prethee, how fell the perjur'd faithleſs man? tell it me o're agen, and I'll reſign my ſelf for ever to thy Arms.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Tell thee and take thee! Were each word Blaſphemy, wou'd every Syllable betray my Life, I'de haſt to utter it for that Reward: though I can tell no more than what I've done already—that we met at a Ball, prepar'd for the contracting of Wellman to Marinda; where I being out in a Dance, or I at leaſt pretending ſo, I ſtruck him, we drew, but being parted there, I challeng'd him out, and it being late, we fought i'th ſtreet, where I had th' Advantage of him and kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: What did you with the Body?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Drag'd it into Fleet Ditch, with the next Tide to flote where Fortune pleas'd, and ſlew my dear Corina—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You ſhall dye for't, fond eaſie Fool—

div.stage: Enter Sir Lyonel, Sir John, and lay hold of him: Wellman from below with Officers.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Seize the Murderer, Oh wicked Villain, baſe and treacherous!

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Baſe and perfidious Woman! hold off your hands, and let me ask this Devil, why ſhe does thus.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ah fool! that cou'dſt believe my Love ſo ſlight to let thee live, that murder'd him I liv'd for.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Well ye Gods! you have reclaim'd my Wildneſs, and brought me back to man,—and now I ſee the Strong Deformity of ſinful Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Come, Come, Sir, we came not here to talk, 'tis Morning already, carry him directly to the Old Baily, the Seſſions is now, and let him be hang'd out of the way.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: You've Reaſon Sir, and deſerve this Uſage, but yet unhand me—thus I'de been ſerv'd had I indeed kill'd Wellman! but Sir he lives, lives at his Goldſmiths, one Gliſter in Cheapſide.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Heavens! Lives! Lives to be married! Oh—

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: We are not to believe that Sir, to Priſon with him till▪ he can prove this true.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: No rudeneſs Sir, I'll go unguarded—Death! what a vile, poor, degenerate thing, a Mercenary Woman is—

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: How, a Mercenary Woman? Where the Devil have I liv'd, and how paſt my time, I knew her not before—this is her Man—I muſt get acquainted with him,—Friend—a Word I pray.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: How Sir, this Woman ſet you on! nay then Mr. Conſtable, pray lay hold of her, and ſee her forth coming.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: With Joy, ſince Wellman lives, and lives to be perjur'd, no matter what becomes of poor loſt me.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: No Sir, let me inſtruct you, take my Word I am a Gentleman, and known to you, ſhe ſhall be forth coming if there be an Occaſion, tho' ſhe be falſe ſhe is a Woman ſtill, a beauteous lovely Woman—come Sir I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I've yet a little Pity on my Heart, and that forſaken Beauty I have ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: But Sir you do not mind me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Said you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: I ask'd you Sir, who this Lady was, to whom I perceive you belong; whether a man may be welcome for his Money—you conceive me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Nay Sir, I ask your Pardon Sir, no Offence I hope; I'am a Knight by Birth Sir, and have Sir, ſome ſixteen hundred a year Sir, no contemptable Fortune for a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: A Gallant Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Whe yes Sir, a Gallant Sir, whe what a Devil, I ſpeak no Treaſon I hope in the Lord.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: But Sir you do as bad, this Lady is of Quality, and has a Fortune too, or if ſhe had not, ſhe has Beauty ſufficient to intitle her to be a wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Say you ſo Friend, I muſt confeſs I am very much taken with her Beauty, but that I have a ſort of an Ingagement upon my Perſon, to Mrs. Diana now, but I like this better by much Sir; and if ſhe can but clear her ſelf of the Buſineſs of this Murder, and has but any reaſonable Fortune—and I get my ſelf off this Diana—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Who is ſhe Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Sir Lyonel Worthy's Daughter Sir, a little learing Titt as any's in England.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Sir to ſerve you, cou'd you help me to the Speech of her, I wou'd do much, and have ſome artful Cunning.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p:
Help thee, whe I'll carry thee immediately man, but do't ſo, as ſhe may be very willing to part with me—or
elſe, poor thing, twill grieve me to diſappoint her.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I'll warrant you for doing that; and clearing this Lady, and ſecuring you a Portion.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: E Gad, and I'm a Man made then—come along thou ſhalt have a handſom Reward for thy Pains too.

div.head: SCENE Sir Lyonel's Houſe
div.stage: Enter Marinda, and Diana, and Maid.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But Siſter is't a Sin to hang one's ſelf?
Is it a Crime to dye when Life's a Torment?
Methinks Heaven ſhou'd forgive it.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Prethee leave theſe Diſputes, ye make me ſad,
A Humour that I hate, and yet for Friendly,
I've try'd to weep and ſigh, and have attain'd to't
With very much adoe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh thou art happy, wou'd I were unconcern'd,
An even brutal Temper that no Miſeries
Cou'd touch, nor Mirth cou'd elevate.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Call you that brutal, give me that ſolid one;
I hate your thin and unſubſtantial Soul
That every ject or ſmall Aſſault of Grief,
Breaks through and makes ridiculous Mirth and Rage,
For every petty accident: Give me a Soul,
A Humour that's in Grain, not one that
Fades like Colours in the Sun, and changes like
Your Cheeks now pale, now red, and tells the World
The Secrets of your Heart; and yet I muſt confeſs I'm
Griev'd for Friendly, for you know I lov'd him,
Yet not ſo much to whine or dye for him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis true, when I conſider he was falſe, methinks I ſhould not dye.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p:
Nay, as for that I think you are miſtaken, I believe him true enough, and that was ſome inſenſed Miſtris, ſome of his Family of Love, that envyed your Happineſs only, and came to put you in Deſpair, and I believe Wellman is not dead, nor can
I think Friendly cou'd be ſo baſe upon any account to kill him; he's virtuous, has ſome Religion in him, and much honeſty, prethee be pacified; come ſit, you have not ſlept to night, ſit and lets ſing to you, and I dare hold you my Diamond Pendants to fifty Guinneys Wellman is alive. Come Ample, ſing a Song.

div.stage: Enter Wellman and Sir John at the door.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir, I have brought you in, now lay your lyes as cloſe together as you pleaſe, do you my bus'neſs, and no matter how: I muſt to the Seſſions houſe this morning to give my Evidence againſt Friendly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Away! I'll hear no more! I cannot ſleep! Alas, there is no Muſick like my ſighs and grones; leave me, and let me go—to reſt, and Wellman!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Ample, ſhe ſwoons, help, help—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: By your leave, ſweet Creatures.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Uncivil Sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: One that brings comfort: hah! the Lady dying! ſtand off, I have a Cordial in my Voice—oh! ſhe's gone, curs'd be my Trial! See, 'tis Wellman calls.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Wellman! ha, ha, ha! Siſter, look up, he's here.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: She ſtirs, give her more Air.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How have I ſlip'd off Life! where am I, hah! in Heaven ſure, and this is Wellman kneeling: Art thou an Angel there?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I would not wiſh it yet, no; we have an Age to come in love e're we arrive to that.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You live then! [ſoftly] I ſhall dy with Joy elſe.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Call back the Blood into thy paled Cheeks, thou Miracle of Women! I made this tryal only to ſecure my Faith, and I believe you love, and I am happy; by all that's good, I never was unjuſt; that Woman, that beauteous Sinner whom you ſaw, I've been to blame with, but you muſt forgive the Errours of my Youth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I do! and her! and muſt love whom you've lov'd.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I thank thy goodneſs, but it ſhall not need, hereafter I'll tell thee all my Life, but now my time is ſhort, and I muſt yet remain in this Diſguiſe 'till Friendly's Tryal's paſt; for he ſhall ſuffer to the laſt degree, for leaving thee, Diana, for another.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: And has he been ſo wicked?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Yes, but is now reclaim'd, but 'twas but in obedience to your Commands, you'd have him try to loſe his Maidenhead, and he forſooth fell deſperately in love, but I'll return the Penitent into your Arms again.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: Faith Brother, I do love the Fugitive, that's flat: and if my Father pleaſe, will marry him; but he's for Sir John Empty.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: But Sir John Empty is not for you, his heart's ingag'd to this Corina, my quondam Miſtris, ſhe ſtrikes all dead that look on her, and I'm to get your conſent he may leave you.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Alas! pray tell him tho' 'twill break my very heart; yet what muſt be, muſt be, Marriages are made in Heaven, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Let me alone: but ſee where he comes breathleſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: News, news, news, news!

sp.speaker: Dia
sp.p: Mackerel, Mackerel, Mackerel, freſh come aſhore.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Whe, how now, Mrs. Marinda! whe, you look blith and brisk upon't.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Whe ay, is not that better than louring, and pouting, and puling, which is troubleſom to the living and vain to the Dead? for my own part, let my Husband laugh at me when I'm dead, ſo he ſmile upon me whilſt I live: I love a chearful countenance in all conditions.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Ay, but to ſee a Woman whine, and yet the Devil a tear falls; mourn, and yet keep her cheeks full.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Ay, there's the Devil.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: And yet I was heartily afraid y faith that I ſhou'd a ſeen a Garland on that Beauty's Herſe; but Time, Truth, Experience and variety, have great power over Woman-kind.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Well Sir, but to the buſineſs, the News you were ſo big with?

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Why, 'tis this: the Publick Seſſions this day holden at the Old Baily has condemn'd poor Frank Friendly.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Hah! Whe Sir, he offered to produce Mr. Wellman at one Mr. Gliſters a Goldſmiths.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: That's all one, when it came to the teſt Gliſter deny'd he ever ſaw or heard of him, and his own Confeſſion hangs him without more witneſs, and with him Daſhit the Vintner is condemn'd for Robbery, and ſeveral others.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: How? Daſhit for Robbery? and was it prov'd againſt him?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Only ſhrewd ſuſpicions, 'tis thought he'l have a Pardon: a Cloak was ſtolen, that Cloak he had. The Juſtice was in Drink that committed him, the Judges ſevere and in haſte, the Jury hungry, and ſo the Knave was caſt; but hang him, he has cheated me with many an unmerciful Bill: but, Lord, to hear his mone, his wiſhes, his curſes, his prayers, and his ill-tim'd Zeal, by my troth, they wou'd have made a Comedy. But, Sir, the Lady, the poor Lady you ſerve, and who betrayed Friendly, is ſent to Newgate; Well, I'll take my Oath 'tis a lovely Gentlewoman, 'tis a thouſand pities; they ſay ſhe muſt be try'd the next Seſſions.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Let me alone for a neat and ſeaſonable lye; [aside.—how Sir, a Lady, pray, who mean ye?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: She that was here, Madam, and gave an account how Wellman was kill'd.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Heav'ns, his Siſter! Mean you Wellman's Siſter Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: How, Wellman's Siſter?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Wellman's Siſter, Madam?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Can you do leſs for an abandon'd Miſtris than tell a handſom lye to get her a good Husband? Say 'tis ſo, or I'll make miſchief.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: The Gentleman knows 'tis ſo: I told him ſhe was of Quality.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: A very virtuous Maid; Heav'ns! that I had but a Brother that wou'd marry her, and take her part in defiance of the World! Nay Siſter, we muſt in Honour viſit her: poor Innocence!

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Hah! Wellman's Siſter? Whe, look ye Madam, tho' you have not a Brother, I wou'd have you to know you have a Lover, that will do as much to ſerve you as any Lover in Chriſtendom, and as for marrying her, for your ſake, Madam, and to do the Lady good, I'de venture as far as Hercules, de ye ſee, or Alexander the Great, that I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Moſt Heroically ſpoken, the Contents do almoſt break my heart, yet, Sir, to let you ſee I ſcorn to be out-done in Bravery, I'le—give you leave—to marry her; and I think that's a bold word.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Egad and ſo 'tis.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay if you are ſo reſolv'd, and keep that Reſolution, 'twill not be hard to bring the Lady off, ſo many Friends joyning to her party.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: For my part I'll dye to ſerve her.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: And ſo will I in blood, now I'm ſet on't,

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Come then, without Delay let's viſit her,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Where? At New-gate Siſter?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: At New-gate: Oh let not that Word fright you, becauſe ſo many have gone to the Gallows from thence! martyr'd Innocence does often dye where Thieves and Robbers do; a Gallows may be ſanctify'd, why not a Priſon? Come Sir John your hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And Sir I muſt beg yours.

div.stage: Great-gate. SCENE changes to the Front of New-gate at the Grate two or three Priſoners, one a beging, a Box hangs out.
[Begs in a low Voice, and crys the while.

sp.speaker: 1 Priſ.
sp.p: Pray remember the poor Priſoners, the poor Priſoners, pray remember the poor Priſoners. ho, ho, ho!

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Dam ye for a Son of a Whore, how ſneakingly do you beg—Remember the Poor—ye meeching Bitch, is that a Voice to dive to the Bottom of a Uſurers Pocket, and fetch out Money in deſpight of his harden'd heart?—Remember the Poor? Pox of your ſnivelling, ſtand by ye Dog, and let me come to the Grate.

sp.speaker: 1 Priſ.
sp.p: Alas, Mr. Shamock, me thinks we ſhould have little Stomach to beg, I hear our Reprieves are out of Doors, and they talk of a Warrant for Execution, ſo that we may be hang'd to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Why you whining Cur, be hang'd to Morrow? whe then we have the more need to beg hard to day, that we may drink at parting; Sirrah beg me heartily and with a good impudent Grace, I'll beat out your Brains with your own Fetters.

sp.speaker: 1 Priſ.
sp.p: Oh! hold, hold, ſpare my Life good Mr. Shamock.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: So, I ſee thou bear'ſt a Conſcience, and wo't not cheat the Gallows of it's due.

sp.speaker: 1 Priſ.
sp.p: Oh no Sir, I have too much Repentance to wiſh to dye ſo wickedly, as I have liv'd; I wou'd go out of the World like a good Chriſtian however.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a chicken-hearted Son of a Whore? thou wert ever a lazy Raſcal, and I remember when we were getting a painful Living on the Kings High-way, wou'dſt ſleep the while, yet wake to ſhare the ſnack, and to be drunk for Joy of the Prize: Stand away and obſerve me now, with what a laudable Voice I'll move Compaſſion:
sp.stage: [Pulls off his Periwig, turns his Cravate behind, thruſts out his Head and begs in a canting Tone.
sp.p: Chriſtians pitty the poor Priſoners of this loathſome and diſmal Dungeon, and 'twill be reſtored unto you in tenfold; drop your Bounty into this little Box, the only Support, Relief, and Comfort of twenty wretched Souls.
Noble Sir, Remember the poor Priſoners:
sp.stage: [He pulls out a long Purſe and puts in a two-pence.
sp.p: The Lord reward your noble Charity, and reſtore it to you forty and forty fold.

'tis an old Oliverian two-pence, a damn'd Commonwealths pair of Breeches, confound the mark and your good Worſhips Bounty, was this all the large Lethern Purſe and your more large Conſcience cou'd produce, wou'd I were worthy to have a Dive or two at your reverend Pockets, I wou'd eaſe 'em for you with a Pox.
Hah! Ladies alighted—

Moſt beautiful Ladies, diſpenſe your noble Charity amongſt twenty miſerable Wretches, oppreſt with Hunger and Cold: Merciful and fair—pity the Miſeries of unfortunate young men; whoſe few ſhort hours of Life they've left, ſhall be imploy'd in Prayers for you our noble Benefactors: Oh remember the Poor!
Sweet Lady, Heaven reward your Beauty with eternal Bloom and numberleſs Adorers.
sp.stage: [Pulls up the Box, they go in.
sp.p: Hah Gold! 'tis Gold by Jove.
Nay, now a ſhort Life and a merry, we'l have it all in drink Boys, and when the Hour comes, dye like Hero's, ſing the Pſalm merrily, and then—be hang'd till we're ſober.

sp.speaker: 1 Priſ.
sp.p: Ah! Mr. Shamock 'tis a long Nap we ſhall take e're we wake again.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: No matter, then we ſhall not be dry next Morning.

sp.speaker: 1 Priſ.
sp.p: Oh this is ſad jeſting—Oh, Oh, Oh!

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Here's a cowardly Rogue, now Plague on him, he's a ſhame to the noble Function of Padding: Sirrah, you ſhall have no Drink, 'tis thrown away upon the Raſcal.

sp.speaker: 3 Pr.
sp.p: Drink? rot him, let him lap ſalt Water from his Eyes, like a mangy Dog as he is.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Come, come, lets in and drink.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Mr. Shamock, you muſt come down to your Devotion, here's a Parſon come; Mr. Ordinary's ſick; come away.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Pox o' your Ceremonies, a man cannot be hang'd in Peace for your Parſon, and your paultry praying—but come, hang't ſince we muſt obey ſilly Cuſtoms, let's down, and then—to drink, my hearts—go, get ye down.

div.head: SCENE the inſide of the Priſon.
div.stage: Enter Friendly in Irons, with Sir Lyonel, Mr. Daſhet in Irons, Mrs. Daſhet weeping by him, Nan and others: Trickwell diſguis'd like a Parſon, ſeeming exhorting 'em: Corina and Mrs. Dunwel ſnivelling.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No Sir, I do not bluſh, nor are my cheeks grown, pale, tho' I'm condemn'd to dye a ſhameful death.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: No kind of Death is ſhameful but the Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Which I well know is none, Heaven is my witneſs, none.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ah! you are happy Sir!—happy to quit the World in Innocence, for Innocence—is a moſt heavenly thing—for Sir, Innocence is all in all; Innocence is—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Very impertinent in your mouth, Sir,—you ought to have the manners to believe a dying man has other bus'neſs—than to give ear to what you ſay; go preach to the Rabble, Sir, I'm not at leiſure.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ah!—what is ſinful man—ſpeak to him, Sir, to think upon his Soul, his precious Soul; ah, his too precious Soul—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Perhaps I'm not of your perſwaſion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hah! Heaven forbid—I hope you'r not a Papiſt Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If I am, Sir, what then?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What then? whe then Sir, guilty or not guilty, you deſerve to dye, and I'll prove it, and ſtand to't.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prethee leave us, we are ſerious.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Leave yee, yes faith, 'tis-time: you are not worth a Groat.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But is there Sir no hopes of a Reprieve?

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: I'll warrant you Sir, I've Intereſt enough for that.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Upon my Honour, Sir, Wellman is but miſlodg'd, and l've already ſatisfied yee how I came to ſay what I did of his Death to that fair falſe one,—ſure ſome Lethargy has ſeiz'd him, that he appears not, or elſe he's mad, it cannot be unkindneſs, and it wou'd grieve you, Sir, to ſee me dye, and after find me innocent.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: By th' Maſs, and ſo it wou'd, Sir; therefore I'll to Court about your Reprieve immediately; nor need you doubt my Diligence or Succeſs;—but why, thou beauteous Hypocrite, didſt thou betray him thus?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I will not anſwer thee: I own my guilt, and am aſham'd and angry at my Deſtiny: Were Wellman dead, I could endure the reſt, but would not live to ſee him live another's.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Well Sir, fare ye well till anon.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Oh! how I hate what once I ſo ador'd!
He that's born well, and Nobly Educated,
Bleſt with an honeſt Fame, and worthy Friend,
And wou'd with deſperate over-ſight love all
And land himſelf upon this fatal ſhore,
Let him ne're kill, or ſteal, but love a Whore.
sp.stage: Enter Wellman, Marinda, Sir Iohn, Ample and Shatter, Diana.
sp.l: —hah!—what do I ſee?
Now everlaſting Darkneſs cover me
From that dear injur'd killing ſight, Diana.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p:
Nay, do not hide your Face, or turn away—I'm wondrous glad to know where a Maid may find ye when ſhe has need of you; and tho' theſe Chains are ſomething eaſier than thoſe of Matrimony, yet, like a malicious Woman, I am for propoſing a change; faith, what d'ye think on't? dare ye venture? methinks
'twere no ungrateful Leap from the Gallows into a fair young Ladies Arms?—wou'd you not rather cry, Drive away Carman?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh! do not mock my miſeries, Diana!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: By this hand, not I; You may remember, I ſwore never to marry, till the man I lik'd cou'd give me proofs he was a man; you bow'd, and bluſh'd, and talk'd of Maidenheads, and modeſtly proteſted your Virginity; oh, filthy in a man! a man of ſenſe too!—but you'r improv'd, I hear, grown wiſe of late, and given me proofs you are no Block-head; and I, to keep my word, am come to challenge you;—and to put you out of all theſe hanging apprehenſions, know Wellman's alive.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: How! Wellman alive?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: My dear, unkind, have you dealt well with me?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I was reſolv'd I wou'd be quits with you for getting my Miſtreſs from me; which by the way I beg you wou'd forgive. I've a Deſign to marry her to Empty.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: She is a Woman, and I ſcorn to injure her.
—And can you, Madam, except this Criminal in Chains?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: The ſooner for that reaſon, with my Father's leave, I have a good hank upon you when you're inſolent, to upbraid ye with the place from whence I had ye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He cannot but commend your Paſſion for him.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I am aſham'd to be ſo much oblig'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, leave the ſhame to her.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Shame, I laugh at it, and wou'd have believ'd none to have marry'd Friendly under the Gallows—therefore take my hand, and bind the bargain.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Thou art a Noble Creature, and I am thine forever.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: By Heaven, Corina, it was not want of Love, my Fortune did depend upon my Marriage, but when I ſaw the Woman deſtin'd for me, I muſt confeſs I felt new flames poſſeſs me, without extinguiſhing the old, and I reſolv'd to love her virtuouſly, and hold an honeſt Friendſhip ſtill with thee—to raiſe thee up above the Worlds contempt, the fickle favours of unconſtant man, and love thee as my Siſte.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
What pow'rful Charms dwell in thy tender language! thou melt'ſt my rage with every ſoftening look, and lead'ſt me
a tame Captive to thy will;—I am ſtill all thine, diſpoſe me as thou pleaſeſt.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: This Knight, Corina, then reſolve to marry, I'll make thy Fortune equal to his Quality, the man is honeſt, young, and Maſter of himſelf. He thinks thou art my Siſter—nor will I ever undeceive him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Well—ſince I muſt loſe you, and am by your Commands obliged to Life, no matter how forlorn and wretched 'tis—

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: By my troth, Sir, you have left her like a man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Sir Iohn, you are my Friend, and this my onely Siſter, for whom I know you have a Paſſion; and ſince Mrs. Diana is diſpos'd of, I am reſolv'd you ſhall not be diſappointed of a Lady. Take her, and truſt my Friendſhip for her Fortune, 'twill not be inconſiderable.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Fortune Sir! I ſcorn ſhe ſhou'd owe her Ladiſhip to any Fortune but what my ſingle Honour can give.

—therefore Madam, I am your Knight, your Champion, your moſt humble Husband and obedient Servant, Iohn Empty, Baronet: but good Brother, let us make haſte out of this ſcandalous place, it puts me ſo damnably in mind of mortality, it will ſpoil my Wedding-night.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Ay Sir, as ſoon as Friendly's diſcharg'd.

sp.speaker: Marin.
sp.p: You muſt give me leave to call This while Trickwell is ſeeming exhorting the Priſoners, and picking their pockets, Sir John. and Wellm. looking at Trick. & the Pris'ners. your Siſter too, for I muſt love and ſerve all that love Wellman.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Madam, the Generous Pattern that you have ſet me, I ſhall be proud to follow.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Hah, Sure that Wench I know,—'tis ſhe—whe how how now, Nan, what brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: 'Fore Gad e'en my kind heart, Mr. Wellman, Love, villanous Love!

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Hah, Love! whe, what a pox, is that become a hanging matter in our Age?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: If 'twere, your Neck's in no great danger.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Good Lord, what I warrant you think I was never in love then? yes faith have I, and have felt your Flames and Fires, and Inclinations, and Wamblings, as often as any He that wears a head.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Then you are the firſt Fool I ever knew inſpir'd.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: ſpare him Nan, he's my Brother, but prethee ſay how came Love to bring thee to this fatal end?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Fatal! 'tis my Glory—and egad my Statue and Hiſtory ought to be added to the Gallery of Heroick Women—why you have hear'd I ſuppoſe, that my Huſband was condemn'd laſt Seſſions, Mr Shamock.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: What the famous Padder? is he thy Huſband?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yes Faith, he had a Reprieve, but now the Warrant's ſign'd for Execution, and he is to be hang'd to morrow.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Well what's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Whe faith, we have liv'd lovingly hitherto together, and we'll e'ne dye as lovingly, for I am reſolv'd to be hang'd honeſtly with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Honeſtly hang'd—how ſo?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Whe I'll tell you Sir, when the Tidings came to me of poor Iack's being apprehended, I ſoon knew which way the World wou'd go with him; I ne're ſnivel'd and nouted like a feeble Woman for the matter, but e'ne reſolv'd bravely to take a Turn at Tyburn with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Lord have Mercy upon us.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: In order thereunto, what does me I, but hearing of a Fellow that had loſt a parcel of Goods of value, but goes my ways to him, accuſes my ſelf for the Thief, was ſent to Newgate, and to my great Joy and Satisfaction, was condemn'd with honeſt Iack efaith: On my Soul, Mr. Wellman, I trembled for Fear I thou'd have been acquitted, but the honeſt Jury took Pity on me, and brought me in Guilty. When the Devil wou'd any of your Wives of Quality have ſhow'd this conjugal Conſtancy?

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Lord deliver me, what a wicked World is this, that People ſhou'd have the face to confeſs their Villainies! ſhe confeſſes all now, and ſome are hang'd and confeſs nothing.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: And wo't thou be ſo good natur'd to take a Turn with him at the Gallows?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: With as much Joy as e're I kiſs'd him.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Whe this is the moſt admirable Proof of Love, I ever heard off.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Proof of Love, proof of the Devil, Man, what to be ſlain at Tyburn for Love? whe 'tis moſt damnable and as nonſenſical as to be hang'd for Religion.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I find by your Principles that you'l keep out of Harms way.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Nay o'my Conſcience, I ſhall ne're increaſe the Number of the noble Army of the Martyrs.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Nan, where are you, here's the Fellow has brought home our Coffin.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Let him bring't in my dear, you ſhall ſee Mr. Wellman, what a Device I have found out, never to part with dear Jack: I have beſpoke a Coffin to hold us both.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: How a Coffin? Lord have Mercy upon's, how great the Devil is with this Woman! but what care have you taken of your Soul all this while?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: That's the Buſineſs of Mr. Ordinary, he has ſo much a year allow'd him for managing that Affair, and has undertaken mine: Come bring in the Coffin.

div.stage: Enter Fellow with a Coffin, They look on't.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Whe, what a Coffin's here? Is this a Coffin fit for Chriſtians?—D'ye ſee, and all pitch't within too, ye Dog, we ſhall ſtick to't, a pox on ye for a naſty Son of a Whore.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Bleſs me, ſure theſe Reprobates never think of going to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ay! I gave him two broad pieces in hand too, and two more I have in my Pocket to give him—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Which I muſt be acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But he ſhall be damn'd e're he be ſo well paid.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Beſides, Sirrah, you might have had the Manners to have lin'd it with a little Bays this cold Weather, but you have neither Conſcience nor fore-caſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Lord! Brother Wellman, I believe ſome Prieſts have been tampering with 'em, they are ſo wicked.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Ha, Ha, Ha! a notable Obſervation.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: I'de forgot too, I'll lay my Head to a Halter, this Coffin will not hold us both.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Hark ye Friend, don't lay with him, for he's oth' ſurer side.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yes my Dear, as for that I believe we may make Shift, 'tis but my laying my Arm under thy Head, and thou thine over my Breaſt, and we ſhall lye as ſnug theſe cold nights—

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Whe the Devil's in theſe People.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But I have a curſed Misfortune befallen me.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: What's that, my dear Betty?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: The Whore the Laundreſs, who had all the Linnen I was to be buryed in, like an ungrateful Baggage, knowing I was to be hang'd, and ſhe to have no more of my Cuſtom, has pawn'd all, my lac'd Linnen too; ſo that, dear Jack, I ſhall come to thy Arms but ſcurvily equipt to morrow.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Lets arreſt her. Lord, Lord, that People ſhou'd have no Conſcience nor Honeſty in 'em: what will this wicked World come to.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Ay! and to rob the Gallows too, unmerciful Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Young Woman, young Woman, this is no time to think of Trifles, and gew gaws; the beſt dreſs is that of Repentance, let your Conſcience be clean and neat within, and no matter for Lace and Tawdrums; dreſs up your Soul I ſay.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Whe what a Pox have we here?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: One who has preacht better Doctrine to your Ladyſhip e're now, [and] one who am appointed to put you in mind of your long home.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Whe ye Fool you, have I been taking ſuch pains to prepare my ſelf for this Journey, and need your Advice in the Devils name? get ye gone ye canting Raſcal, here's honeſt Jack can teach me how to dye worth a Legion of you formal Gown-men.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Gad thou'rt a noble Laſs.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: In Troth and ſo ſhe is, 'tis Pity ſhe ſhou'd be damn'd.

div.stage: Trick. goes to Daſhet, Betty to the Joyner.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Well Sirrah, here is your two pieces more, becauſe I ſcorn to be worſe than my word— [Feels in her Pocket. hah! my money's gone—what's the meaning of this? I had 'em and the two pieces for Jack Catch too in my Pocket when I came down.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Whe what a Pox have we Thieves amongſt our ſelves? this is fine doings efaith.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Hang't let it go, they are ſome poor Devils that wanted it: go out and wait till I go up, and I'll pay you.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Or let him call again to Morrow in the Evening—

div.stage: Trick. talking this while to Daſhet, he making Grimaces of Wo, and crying and wringing his hands, Mrs. Daſhet crying by him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſhet.
sp.p: Well Husband, this is a very comfortable man.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: He is ſo. But, good Mr. Parſon, leave my Soul a little while to it ſelf, I pray, and let us have a little of your counſel concerning my Body. I owe Mr. Gliſter the Goldſmith 40 l. and ſuppoſe, Mr. Parſon, when I am going to Execution he ſhou'd be ſo unneighbourly as to ſet a Ser jeant upon my back—'twas for a Bowl—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ah! trouble not thy ſelf, my Chriſtian Brother with tranſitory matters, but have an Eye—an Eye I ſay to the main chance— [picking his pocket. I'll warrant your ſhoulders; but as for your neck—Plinius Secundus, or Marcus Tullius Cicero, or ſome body ſays; that a threefold Cord is hardly broken.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: A very Learned man this—well, I am not the firſt honeſt man that has been hang'd, and I hope ſhall not be the laſt.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: True Sir, therefore have a righteous Stomach: for you perhaps may ſup in Heaven to morrow.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Alas, Sin! I have no ſtomach to it at all Sir,—pleaſe you to take my Trencher, I never eat at night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Ah, Husband, I little thought you ſhou'd have had need to have thought of Heaven ſo ſoon: oh!—had you been hang'd deſervedly 'twou'd ne're have troubled me: for there's many an innocent man has been hang'd deſerv'dly,—but to be caſt away for nothing—oh,—oh.—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Comfort your ſelf, good Miſtris, moderate Grief is decent, you'l ſhortly be a Widow, and I'm a Batchelor; I'll come and viſit ye, and give you Chriſtian conſolation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Ah, Sir! you ſhall be heartily welcome, and pray make haſte.—oh—oh—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Well,—I do here make my Confeſſion before all good Chriſtian People, and do declare—that if I owe any man any thing, I do heartily forgive him.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: In truth, Religiouſly ſpoken. Whe, this is ſomething.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: But—but, if any manowes me any thing, let him pay my Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: A good reaſon too y faith.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: There—are—the Writings of that Rogue's Eſtate who has brought me to this untimely End—dear Writings to me, God knows.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: Where had you theſe?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I took 'em out yeſterday, thinking to have carry'd 'em to my Lawyers, in order to taking the forfeiture of 'em: now thou may'ſt do't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Da.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Husband, I'll warrant'ye, I ſhall be diligent.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: And now, good Yoke-fellow, take leave of thy honeſt and true Daſhet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: No, Husband, an't pleaſe the Lord I'll not leave you now,—I'll ſee you hang'd firſt—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hah, my writings! now for a trick of dexterity to retrieve thoſe, and I'm a man again— [aſide] but Brother, you muſt remember your ſins too, and iniquities; you muſt conſider you have been a Broacher of prophane Veſſels, you have made us drunk with the juice of the Whore of Babylon: for whereas good Ale, Perry, Syder, and Metheglin, were the true Ancient Britiſh and Trojan Drinks, you have brought in Popery, meer Popery—French and Spaniſh Wines, to the ſubverſion, ſtaggering, and overthrowing of many a good Proteſtant Chriſtian;—oh! remember the Sins of the Cellar, beloved, the Mid-night ſins that have been unſavoury to the taſts of your Cuſtomers, when you put the change upon 'em: remember your double ſcorings and long Bills, ah, remember your long Bills.
sp.stage: [this while he picks Mrs. Daſhets pocket of the Writings.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: This is that Rogue Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Ah! I confeſs, I confeſs, and forgive. [cryes.—has any heard of one Trickwell?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Trickwell; yes, I know him well: a very honeſt Religious man, and an unright Dealer with his Neighbours, and their Wives ſpeak well of him.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I'll take it upon my Death he's the cauſe of my hanging, but I heartily forgive him; and if he wou'd but yet come forth and ſave me, I wou'd ſet him free from the Law, and diſcharge him for injuring me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: And wou'd you from the bottom of your Soul forgive him all his cheats and Rogueries?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I wou'd, and be bound in a thouſand pound Bond to ſave him from the Law: ah! but 'tis impoſſible—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Why look ye, Sir,—behold, your worſhipful Friend and humble Servant Thomas Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hah! diſcovered by Mr. Wellman.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Trickwell!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Now bawling Mr. Daſhet.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Who wou'd have look't for a Wolf in Sheeps cloathing? or a Knave in a Parſon's Gown?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No railing Daſhet, if you do, I'l ſwear againſt you yet.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Ay do, and damn your Soul.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What with a little Perjury? the Lord have Mercy on our Age then: No, no Sir, I'll retrieve you from the Gallows, but as for your Goods and Moneys it muſt go towards the uſe of my two hundred pound a year, which you have kept me from this two years, and of which now, thanks to my Dexterity, I ſtand again poſſeſt.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: How my Writings gone?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Thank God you're ſo rid of them, for I had been an eternal Rent charge upon you elſe, if I had not hang'd you: you know you had 'em for a little damn'd ballderdaſh Wine—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Well, I'de better looſe my Writings than my Life.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Hold Trickwell;—yonder Woman I have been oblig'd to, and you have had Relief from—no Writings nor Pardon under marrying Mrs. May here—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, what a Bawd?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: The better Sirrah, ſhe has a good Calling then, when all fails.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Gods Bleſſing of your heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: No grumbling, do't or I'le deliver:—remember Sirrah how you uſed my Miſtreſs laſt night, and had the Impudence to rival me—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well Sir of two Evils I'll chuſe this—give me thy hand Moll, thou'ſt been a loving Soul I muſt confeſs.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: So there's ſome Revenge, I cou'd even cry for Joy now,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Daſh.
sp.p: And ſo cou'd I too, if I knew for what.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Here, where's Mr. Friendly—here's your Reprieve Sir, Hah! Marinda and Diana!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Yet with their Husbands Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: How, How?—hah! Mr. Wellman alive? and with Mr. Friendly—God bleſs ye, God bleſs ye all, I'm glad on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Ay Sir, and I am maryed to this Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: I'm glad of that too.
Here Mrs. Betty, where are you? Here's a Reprieve come for you:

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Hah a Reprieve! What Devil ow'd me this malicious Spight, a Reprieve—dam thee, thou ill, thou ominous looking Dog, ever the Meſſenger of Helliſh Tidings: Oh! I cou'd tear thy hated Tongue out—Rogue—

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Nay, dear, better be patient, and if we muſt part.—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: Art thou turn'd cruel too, and preacheſt Patience?
Patience with Life—no, I defie my Fate—
Scorning to live without thee thou ſhalt ſee,
I'll find a thouſand ways to dye with thee.—

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: By 'th Maſs a hearty Wench I'll warrant her, but come let's away: good Boys let's home and Dance, but firſt give Money to theſe poor Wretches.
From this dire place many to Death have gone,
But to be marry'd, very rarely one.
